The discoveries that have been made about the Inca, Puebloans, and the Plavlopetri are important. Some of the things we use today have been created by these three cultures. These things help us in our daily lives. Also, the things invented have helped change the world.            Discoveries that have been made by the Inca are important because they created a quipus to record the calandar and keep track of livestock. The Inca also left behind clues such as portraits that displayed their religion, art, architecture, agriculture, government, transportation and way of life. Lastly, the Inca were buried in caves in cliff faces so looters couldn't easily get to them. These discoveries that have been made of the Inca are important.            Discoveries that have been made by the Puebloans are important because the skills for basketmaking are still used today. The Puebloans learned how to make pottery and weapons by using their skills in basketmaking. The Puebloans also invented kivas. Kivas were underground chambers that were ceremonial rooms. This was similar to a church and helped Puebloans gather and make places to weave baskets. These discoveries that have been made of the Puebloans are important.            Discoveries that have been made by the Plavlopetri are important because without these discoveries, nobody would know about how a sunken city may have submerged. Archaeologists have discovered that the Plavlopetri had created over 9,000 square meters of new buildings. This suggested that the town had been used by an elite and raised the status of the settlement. Also, the settlement might have been sank by sea level changes, ground subsidence; earthquakes or a tsunami. These discoveries that have been made by the Plavlopetri are important.            These discoveries that have been made about the Inca, Puebloans, and the Plavlopetri are important. These discoveries have helped archaeologists make assumptions of the lives of these three cultures. These discoveries have also shown archaeologists how the lives of these three cultures were lived. This is why discoveries of the Inca, Puebloans, and the Plavlopetri are important.

We today often are learning things about history on a regular basis, but you may think, how do we know these things? It's simple, we learn things by either kept records, passed down stories, or in older cases, archeological discoveries.  Archeologists go to many ancient civilization settlements and make new discoveries almost everyday.  While some discoveries seem boring and not important, archeological discoveries are one of the main things that shapes the way we see the past and how we are now in the present.  These discoveries have given us information about a few specific civilizations, the Inca, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri.  Foundings on these ancient civilizations are some of the very things that have created the way man-kind is today.         Many artifacts found in ancient civilizations show records; perhaps of stories or just some sort of writing.  For example, the Inca had no alphabet or form of writing, but they kept track of their livestock and made a calendar all using different colored string called quipus (Ancient Inca). The development of today's language could have very well started with strings the way that the Inca did.  Records about the Inca were also kept by the Spanish, who came to the empire in 1532; they wrote about the Inca in their language and much was learned about the Inca from just that.  To justify what was learned by the spanish cam from artifacts found such as pottery and textiles (Ancient Inca).  These artifacts could very well also show the development of tools and art throughout history and how we are today.        Discoveries about civilization can also effect how we and why we build houses and buildings the way we do today.  The Puebloans were ancient settlers in Mesa Verde, and were well know as skilled craftsmen and basket makers.  The Puebloans made certain types of houses called pithouses.  These houses have support beams and a fire pit with an air deflector (Mesa Verde).  In today's world we have kept a similar method of having good support and fireplaces and chimneys in our houses.  These pithouses later evolved into Kivas, these were very similar but a better design.  Both of these houses had a symbolic hole in the ground called a sipapu, that represented a passage to the underworld (Mesa Verde).       Much like how the symbolic passage to the underworld for the Puebloans, Archeological discoveries can explain myths and legends that we learn about in today's world.  For example, the discovery of the Pavlopetri perfectly explains the legend of the under water city Atlantis.  The Palvlopetri is a sunken settlement off the coast of Greece.  This settlement is likely to be one of the oldest sunken cities their is, with ceramics dating back to the stone age.  We have all heard the stories about a mythical Atlantis and this discovery explains why those stories came to be, just like many archeological discoveries guide us to how today's world is.

The discoveries that have been made about the Inca, Puebloans, and Pavlopetri are so important because if we don't know anything about them then we wouldn't have some of the modern things we have today. We also wouldn't have some of the modern architecture because some of the buildings we have today are based off of the buildings they had.       The Inca were a very large empire. They rivaled the the expanse of ancient Rome. Some of the clues that the Inca left behind are a big 'window' to their lives. Stories were also passed down by the Europeans who took over the empire. The Spaniards were not very fluent in the Inca language so they may not have been very accurate with their stories of Inca history. Artifacts left behind are something else that give us some history. Pottery made of stone, silver, and gold lasted hundreds of years buried under ground; some were even found in graves for the dead to use in afterlife. Inca textiles and clothing also shockingly lasted just as long. Ancient cloth usually gets ruined by dampness, but these survived in the dry deserts of Peru or the cold Andes mountains.       About 1,400 yeas ago, Mesa Verde was chosen to be home for a group of native American peoples called the Puebloans or 'the ancient ones'.  For over 700 years they flourished in this area, building elaborate stone communities in the cannon walls. The Puebloans were known as basket-makers. Beginning as nomads they started to lead a more settled life. they replaced hunting with farming, and lived in small one room houses called pit-houses. Thel later began to build houses above ground out of poles and adobe. The baskets that they made show a decline in quality stating that the widespread use in pottery means less attention to the craft.       In the waters of Southern Grese a sunken settlement is thought to be the inspiration of the myth Atlantis. This site straddles 30,000 square meters of the ocean floor. the findings surpassed all expectations; there were buildings, courtyards, main streets, rock-cut tombs, and religious structures as well as thousands of shards from pottery. Then after exploration there were 9,000 more square meters of new buildings. Marine geologists have no idea why the city could have sunk: earthquake, tsunami, or just a rise in sea level. It is the firs sunken city discovered in Grece that predates the tale of Atlantis.

The Inca, Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri

Archeologists are people that study ancient things including    civilizations. Some important civilizations are the Incas, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri. They are all important archeology sites.   Inca was one of these important places. Incas had no system of    alphabet or writing. They made quipus, knots made of colored string, that were used to record the calender and keep count of livestock. No one in the present knows how to read the  quipus. Some of what we know about Incas comes from stories passed from generation to generation. Some things we know because of the Europeans who visited the Inca empire in 1532, they described the Incas in letters and diaries.   Inca textiles and clothing have also survived. Other Inca sites    have been disturbed by looters that took anything of value. Looted sites don't offer much to archeologists.   Another important civilization was the Puebloans. They lived in   Mesa Verde , they lived there for 700 years building elaborate stone communities. They were skilled at making baskets and pottery. They farmed instead of hunting and gathering, and lived in small villages. They used alot of sand stone shaped into rectangular bricks. They deserted Mesa Verde by about 1300 AD. No one knows the reason that they left, but there are many theories.   The last important cililization was the Pavlopetri. This lost city that might have inspired the myths of atlantis. It was sunken 5000 years agoo, and it is the oldest submerged town in the world.

Ancient Civilization       Incas lived in ancient Peru during the years of 1438-1532. They had no writing system or education like we do today. They some left clues for scientists to discover. The clues left behind form their religion, art and architecture, government, agriculture, transportation, and ways of life. We know some stories from writings by the Europeans. Spanish soilders and priests also described the Inca in letters and diaries. The rest of our knowledge comes from artifacts discovered. These treasures have led to the facts we know about Incas.       Another group of people we know about are Puebloans. The first Puebloans settled in Mesa Verde about A.D. 550. They were skilled in craft making. They were forming a more settled life style. Farming replaced hunting and gathering. They lived in pit houses clustered into small villages. By A.D. 1000 the people of Mesa Verde had advanced from pole-and-adobe construction to skillful stone masonary. Ancestral Puebloans lived in the cliff dwellings for less than 100 years. They migrated out of Mesa Verda due to drought and crop failure. The Pueblo people of today are descendants of the smart and strong Ancestral Puebloans.       A team of geologists have found an under sea city in Greede called Peloponnese. They had found ceramics dating back to the end of the stone age. Their investagations also revealed over 9000 square meters of new buildings. They still haven't figured out why the settlement sank. The team says, 'Atlantis was a myth but it is a myth that keeps underwater exploration going. Less than 1 percent pf the world's ocean floors have been surveyed. This is an extraordinary find but there is still a lot more down there that has to be found.'       If it wasn't for these teams for discovering and testing out these lost places we would know nothing about. Anicient civilization is very interesting. Finding more and more never explored places is fascinating and scary. That's what keeps them going and trying to succeed. Their hard work is what educates us today. Also our Ancestrys' hard work led us to the technology we have today.

Ancient Archeology   On Source #1 it says, 'The ancient Inca of Peru had no formal alphabet or system of writing.' It talks about the systems the past had. They did not leave any form of history to study. 'The Inca made knots in colored strings called quipus to record the calender to keep count of livestock.' The first Europeans were so amazed that the Inca could  run a large empire using strings to keep records. Today no one knows what the knots meant. 'Some of what we know about the Inca comes from oral history...'        The reason we know some of the old stories, because they were written down by the Europeans who arrived in the empire in 1532. 'The Inca lived high in the Andes and may even have worwshiped some mountain peaks. Many of their sites are in remote, high places. Some Inca were buried in caves in cliff faces, for example, or on mountain tops. This has helped to preserve the sites, because looters cannot easily get to them. But it also makes the job of the archaeologist more difficult. High-alltitude archaeologists are expert mountaineers. They have to carry all their equipment up a mountain before they can start work. Anything they find has to be carried down the mountain for study. The cold mountains act like a giant freezer. Bodies found in the icy Andes are in such good shape that experts can use modern edical scanning equipment to learn about how the people died. The bodies also reveal information about how they lived.'       Section #2 says that the first Ancestral Puebloans settled in Mesa Verde about A.D. 550. There were people that lived in pithouses from about A.D. 550 to A.D. 750, as settled agriculture began .        'Ever since local cowboys first reported the cliff dwellings in the 1880's, archeolagists have sought to understand these people's lives.' 'Fires built in summer were mainly for cooking.In winter, when the alcove rooms were damp and uncomfordable, fires probably burned throughout the village. Smoke-blackened walls and ceilings are reminders of biting cold these people lived with for several months each year.       Section #3 is about exploring the underwater worlds. The secrets of a lost city that may have inspired one of the world's most enduring myth's - The fable of Atlantis - have been brought to light from beneath the waters off southern Grrece. The seas have been explored by many people. ' There is no doubt that this is the oldest submerged town in the world,' Said Dr Jon Henderson

The Puebloans lived in tiny pithouses that were clustered into towns, and they relied on farming. From what any clues that were left behind tell us, the Puebloan people were formerly nomadic, and they were looking for a more settled lifestyle. Last, but certainly not the least, the Pavlopetri people were, in my opinion, the most interesting. In Greece, a submerged city was found by Pavlopetri people. Without them, this sunken Greece city wouldn't have be found when it was. I always thought sunken cities were just a myth. Maybe Atlantis could be real!            All in all, the findings of the Inca, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri people have been an amazing discovery. It's just one more thing to add to the history book. Finally, answers were found. We don't have to worry about the Inca, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetris people's history any longer.

Lost Civilizations       Ancient Inca   The ancient Inca, found in Peru, doesn't have any formal system of writing. Instead they use colored strings and knots to communicate and keep records. Today nobody truly knows about what these quipus, colorful strings and knots, mean. Even though we don't know what the quipus means, we do know other interesting information about the Inca. We know things like religion, art, agriculture, government , transportation and way of life. We know some of the information we know from the Europeans who had written down stories in letters and diaries of what the Inca were like, when the Europeans first arrived in the 1532. Historians had to be careful when reading these letters and diaries because the Europeans did not speak the Inca language and may have misunderstood what the Inca had said. Other knowledge about the history of the Inca comes from artifacts, and other objects that they left behind. Most of the Inca textiles were preserved int eh dry deserts on the Peru coast or in the cold Andes mountains. Some of the Inca sites were ruined by treasure hunters or looters, who take anything that they might think is valuable. Looted sites do not tell archaeologists very much, because non-looted sites give the best idea about the life of the Inca, because nobody has moved or touched anything. This is also why when archaeologists study sites they photograph and write down the exact position in which they find artifacts. Artifacts from the Europeans shoe that the Inca fell in 1532 when the Spaniards murdered the Inca king and took over the empire. Other artifacts that were found are harder to trace to the Inca because after the Inca had fallen to the Spaniards many different peoples had lived in the same area as them. Archaeologists do know that the Inca lived high places like the Andes mountains and the Inca even worshiped some mountains peaks. The Inca were also buried in high places such as, cliff faces, caves, and mountain tops. Because the Inca liked to live in high elevated areas, this actually helped archaeologists because looters cannot easily get to the sites and also because the mountains like a big freezer. Any body that was found was in good shape that they could use modern medical scanning ans equipment to learn how the person had died, and how they lived daily. This also made the archaeologists jobs more difficult because archaeologists would have to carry all their equipment up to the site before they could start to work, also anything they found would have to be carried down the mountain so it could be studied closer.       Ancestral Puebloans   Close to 1,400 years ago, people that were living in the Four Corners region moved to Mesa Verde. For about 700 they lived and flourished here. They built stone communities in canyon walls and beneath overhanging cliffs.Which is now preserved in Mesa Verde National Park. Archaeologists have called people who lived in these communities Anasazi, which is Navajo word for 'the ancient ones' or 'ancient enemies' and are now called Ancestral Puebloans. A Puebloan is a Spanish word for village dwellers. These people were also known as the basketmakers because of their skill and craft for basket making. They aslo had skill for making pottery and acquired the bow and arrow. They farmed, hunted, and gathered as a way to get food for their families. They lived in pithouses that clustered into small villages that were usually built on mesa tops and in cliff recesses. In 750 A.D. the Basketmakers started to build houses above ground. These houses were agianst each other in long, curving rows. They usually had one or two pithouses in front of their actual house. By 1000 A.D. the Mesa Verde people had advanced to stone masonry. Walls on buildings were thick, double-coursed, rose two or three stories high and joined into units of fifty rooms and sometimes more. These walls are regarded as the finest ever built by the Mesa Verde. During this time, pottery also changed. It changed from smiple designs and gray background to black drawings on a white background. Farming was big during this time as well. Farming accounted for more of their deit than ever before and much of the mesa-top land was cleared for farming. Baskets declined in quality, possibly because the use of pottery was higher that meant less interest in baskets at the time. In about 1200 A.D. the people of the Mesa Verde moved back onto/into cliffs alcoves that homes the ancestors many centuries before. The structures of the cloff dwellers are evidence of a society that over centures gained many skills and traditions and passed them through the generations. By the Classic Period the population reached several thousand.  This is also whent he accomplishmants of the Mesa Verde had among the finest expressions of human culture in North America.   In the beginning the basic material for construction was sandstone. They shaped the sandstone into rectangular blocks, the size of a loaf of bread. In between the blocks were a mixture of maud and water. They stacked these block on top of each other, and aside each other to make rooms. These rooms averaged about six feet by eight feet, there was room for about two or three people. In the upper levels the generally stored crops. The underground rooms were ceremonial chambers, and eventually front rooms. Their roofs created open courtyards where daily routines took place. In the summer, they built fires to cook. In the winter,  fired burned throughout the village. Smoke from the fires blackened walls and ceilings.   Around 1300 A.D., Mesa Verde was deserted. Theories why they moved were: migration,  drought and crop failures, land and resources were depleted, and social and political problems took place. When the cliff dwellers left they traveled south into Arizona and New Mexico.       Lost Greek City   The lost Greek city is located of the waters of southern Greece and known as the oldest submerged town int eh world. This sunken settlement dates back to 5,000 years ago and consumed by the water around 1000 BC. It has artifacts dating back from 2800 to 1200 BC. The lost Greek city lays on 30,000 aquare meters of ocean floor. The shifting sands and the settlement's encosure in a protected bay help to save most buildings, courtyards, main streets, rock-cut tombs, pottery and religious structures from being destroyed. Many think that this cite sank because of sea level changes, earthquakes, or tsunami.

The rest of our knowledge of the Inca comes from artifacts, or objects that they left behind, and from the sites where artifacts are found. As many ancient civilizations, Inca artifacts might be objects made from stone, pottery, gold, silver. Materials last a long time, even if they have been buried for hundreds of years. Artifacts turn up in the ruins of buildings. Others are found buried in graves for the dead to use in the afterlife.                      Some treasure were taken centuries ago, but looting still goes on today. Looted sites often do not tell archeologists very muvh. Sites are reported to archeologists, who can dig them up carefully. They provide the  best idea of all about life in peru before and during Inca rule. Archeologists  who study these sites keep careful records. They write down and phtograph any artifcats they find, and note the exact position in which they find them, and they need to learn as much information as they can from every single piece of evidence. The fall of Inca is easy to date because the spaniards murdered the last Inca king in 1532 and took over the empire. The orgins of the Inca are more difficult to trace. The area where they lived had long been inhabited by different peoples. Archeologists have to be careful to make sure  exactly which people built which site. This has helped to preserve the sites , because looters cannot easily get to them, but it also makes job of the archeologist more diffucult . high altitude archeologists are expert mountaineers. They have to carry all their equipment up a mountain before they can start work. The cold mountains act like a giant freezer. Bodies found in the icy andes are in such good shape that experts can use modern medical sacnning equipment to learn about how the people died. The bodies also reveal information about how they lived                       In the future archeologist will use more techniques in the worl to discover more about the Incas predeccessors.

The Inca left some clues behind show amazing portraits of their lives like their religion, art, architecture, agriculture, transportation, and their ways of living. Studying these clues some archaeologistt are able to piece together some of Inca life.Some old stories are told about the IInca, by Europeans who arrived in their empire in 1532 and described them in their diaries and lettters.       most of our knowledge  about the inca come from artifacts, or objects that they have left behind. In many ancient civilizations the Inca artifacts might be objects that are made from stone, pottery, gold, or even silver. Even though they have been buried for hundreds of years some of these magnifacent artifacts turn up in the ruins of buildings. Others are found buried in graves of the dead for them to use in their after life.       Some ancient textiles and clothing have also been found and havbe survived remarkably well. Some materials like cloth were usually destroyed by dampness, but these items were preserved in the dry deserts on Peru's coast or the cold mountains of the andes.But sadly some inca sites have been disturbed by treasure hunters or looters. they will take anything that is valuable.Most of the treasures were taken centuries ago, but looting still goes on today.       The fall of the Inca is easy to date back because the Spaniards murdered the last Inca king in 1532 and then soon after toook over the empire. The origons of the Inca however are much more difficult to trace because the area where they live had long been inhabited by many different people.They lived high in the Andes and may have even worshiped some mountain peaks.Many of their sites are in remote , high places. Some Inca were buried in caves in cliff faces. But ths has helped preserve the sites , because loooters can't easily get to them.       The high mountains are vey cold, so cold that they act as a giant freezer. Bodies are found in the icy Andes are in such good shape that experts can use modern medical scanning equipment to learn how the people died. the bodies also reveal information about how they lived.                Long ago about 1,400 yaers ago Europeans explored North America. A group of people lived there in the Four Corners religon chose Mesa Verde for their home. For over 700 years they and their decendants live and flourished here,eventually building building elaborate stone communities in the sheltered alcoves of the canyon walls. Then, in the late A.D 12000s, in the span of a gereration or two, they left their homes and moved away.       Mesa Verde national park preserves a spectacular reminder of this ancient culture.Archeologists have called these people Anasazi, from a Navajo word sometimes translated as 'the ancient ones' or 'ancient enemies'. We now calll them the Ancestral Puebloans, reflecting their modern descendants.       The first Ancestral Puebloans settled in Mesa Verde about A.D. 550. They are also known as 'Basketmakers' for their skill at crafts.Farming replaced hunting and gathering as their main livelihood. They lived in pithousees clustered into small villages usually built on mesa tops but sometimes in cliff recesses. they learned to make pottery and acquired th bow and arrow, a more efficient wepon for hunting than the altatl , a sper thrower.       About A.D. 750 they began building houses above gorund, with up right wallls made of poles and mud. They built the houses one against another in long, curving rows, often with a pithouse or evn two in front. From here on these people are known as puebloans, a spanish word meaning 'village dwellers'. 1000 A.D the people of Mesa Verde had advanced from pole-and-adobe construction to skillful stone masonry. Walls of thick , doubled-coursed stone often rose twoor three stories high and were joined together into units of 50 rooms or more. Pottery also changed , form simple designs on a dull gray background to black drawings on a white background. Farming accounted for more of their diet than before, and much mesa-to land was cleared for agriculture.       A.D 12000, another major population shift saw people begin to move back to the cliff alcoves that sheltered their ancestors centuries before. Why did they move ? we dont really now why. Perhaps it was for defence; perhaps it was a religious or psychological reasons.Or whatever the reason or reasons, it gave rise to the cliff dwellings for which Mesa Verde is mot famous.       When the clifff dwellers of Mesa Verde left, they traveled south into New Mexico and Arizona, settling among their kin who were already there .       .    The secrets of a lost city that may have inspired one of the most enduring myths- the fable of Atlantis- have been brought to light beneath the waters off southern Greece. this site, which strattles 30,000 square meters of ocean floor off the southern Pel0oponnese, is believed to have been consumed by the sea around 1000 B.C. What they found surpassed all expectations.       Thanks to the shifting of sand and the settlement's enclousure in a protected bay, the exploration revealed a world. A world of buildings , court yards,main streets , rock-cut ombs and religious structures. In addition, the seabed was replete with thousands of shards of pottery.       Marine geologists have yet to work out why the settlement sank.Theories include sea level changes , ground subsidence as the result of earthquakes, or a tsunami.       'Atlantis was a myth but it is a myth that keeps under water explorations going ' said Sakellarious. ' this is and extrordinary find but there is still alot more down there that has to be found'.

Last I am going to talk about Atlantis the   lost civilization. 'There is no doubt that this is the oldest submerged town in the world,' said Dr jon Henderson, associate professer or underwater archaeologist of the University of  Nottingham. It has remains dating from 2800 to 1200 BC, long before the glory days of classical Greece. The site, which straddles 30,000 square meaters of ocean floor off the southern Peloponnese, is believed to have been consumed by the sea around 1000 BC. It was discoverd by a British oceanographer some 40 years ago , it was this year that marine archaeologist, aided by digital technology, were able to properly survey the ruins. What they found surpassed all expectations. thanks to shifting sands and the settlement's encloseure in a protected bay, the exploration revealed a world of buildings, courtyards, main streets, rock-cut tombs and religious structures. Throughout the past, many ancient civilizations have rose to power just to be destroyed by the climate, geography, or other power craving humans. Today, we try to solve the mysteries of who lived on this Earth before us. There is no main reason for our obsession with the past other than utter curiosity. It is human nature to want to know where we have come from and to find connections between now and previous societies. Perhaps it is necessary to know what has already happened so we can change the outcome if the same circumstances occur.                         Three major ancient civilizations that connect us to our past are the Incas, from what is now Mexico, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri. Because of our natural curiosity to know what came before us, archeologists have dug up and studied these ancient civilizations and have used artifacts, items found in the ruins of past civilizations, to piece together the mystery of who they were, what they did, and how they ended. From the Incas, we learned that they kept track of live-stalk, citizens, and calenders with knotted strings called quipus. We also have journals and records from the invading Europeans that explain the invasion then downfall of the Empire.                 Another lost settlement that we have recently discovered and studied is a civilization found underwater off the coast of present-day Greece. There, divers found ceramics almost as old as the stone age and other interesting artifacts to help us learn about the mysterious city. Their downfall is extremely self evident as the entire city is now submerged underwater.                 We can learn many things from these past civilizations. For example, with the clues archeologists have found, we now know how the civilizations were destroyed. The Incans were attacked by Spanish and other Europeans who wanted power and were just greedy for land. On the other hand, The city that used to be in Greece wasn't invaded but ruined due to the climate and geography. Because it was so close to the ocean, the waves engulfed the entire city and has hidden it under the sea for over 5,000 years.                 It is important that we know what happened that ruined these ancient civilizations so it wont be repeated. Eleanor Roosevelt once said, 'learn from other people's mistakes for you wont live long enough to make them all yourself.' This holds very true to how we should live our lives today. As we have learned from the ancient Incas, it is necessary to have military protection to keep greedy power craving societies away. Also, we have learned by example to never build a society near the ocean because unlike placement of our homes, the weather is uncontrollable. As help from past civilizations guides us and the curiosity to know our origins drives us forward, our society will always be interested in studying and piecing together the mysteries of the life that came before us. However, we must be careful about not dwelling on the past because what has happened is over and cannot be changed. We must use the knowledge gathered from previous events to lead us into greater things in the future.

The ancient Inca of Peru had no formal alphebhet or system of writing. The Inca made knots in coloredstrings called quipus to record the calender to keep a count of livestock. Archaeologists have found many ancient quipus, but today no one knows what the knots mean. Clues left behind by the Inca form an amazing portrait of their religion, art and artitecture, argiculture, government, transportation, and way of life. By studying these clues, archaeologists and others can piece together details of Inca life.         Some of what we know about the Inca comes from oral history, or stories passed from generation to generation. Passing on the stories was an important way to preserve a community's history. Some Inca textiles and clothing have also survived remarkably well. Ancient materials like cloth are usually destroyed by dampness, but these have been preserved in the dry deserts on Peru's coasts or the cold mountains of the Andes. Archaelogists who study these sites keep careful records. They write them down and photograph any artifacts they find, and note the exact position in which they find them. They need to learn as much information as they can from every single piece of evidence.        Archaeologists can compare what they learn from artifacts and sites with the Spaniards' accounts of the Inca. Sometimes archeology confirms historical record. Amoung the most important things to learn about a civilization are where it came from and what happened to it. The fall of Inca is eay to date because the Spaniards murdered the last Inca king in 1532 and took over the empire. Archaelogists use some of the most advanced techniques in the world to discover more about the Inca's predecessors. About 1,400 years ago, long before Europeans explored North America, a group of people living in the Four Corners region chose Mesa Verda for their home.   Mesa Verde National Park preserves a spectacular reminder of this ancient culture. Archeologists have called these people Anasazi, from a Navajo word sometimes translated 'the ancient ones' as 'ancient enemies.'          Between A.D. 1100 and 1300, during the Classic Period, the population may have reached several thousand. It mostly concentrated in compact villages of many rooms, often with the kivas built inside the enclosing walls rather than out in the open. The stone walls of the large peublos are regarded as the finest ever built in Mesa Verde, with their straight courses of carefully shaped stones. Using nature to advantage, Ancestral Puebloans built their dwellings beneath the overhanging cliffs. Their basic construction material was sandstone that they shaped into rectangular blocks about the size of a loaf of bread.

The bodies that scientists find also reveal information about how they lived.The Puebloans flourished for more than 700 years and built elaborate communities in the sheltered alcoves of the canyon walls. The Puebloans population multiplied. They built houses one against another in long, curving rows, often with a pit house or two in the front. Baskets show evidence of decline in quality, possibly because widespread use of pottery and less attention to craft. Also, scientists have found buildings, courtyards, main streets, rock-cut tombs and religious structures in the Pavlopetri. The seabed was a replete with thousands of shards of pottery. They also found ceramics daring back as far as the stone age, which suggested that the settlement was occupied for some 5,000 years ago, at least 1,200 years earlier than originaly thought. The events, culture, and history of our past civilizations contribute to the importance of the present, because they set the foundation and basis for our future.  The civilizations of the Inca, Ancestral Puebloans, and Ancient Greece, were some of the most important contributors.  They left behind clues that tell the story of how they lived, their culture, traditions passed down from generation to generation, their government and politics, the practice of their religion, the beauty of their art, and the planning of their architecture.  Studying these clues lead to a gateway of understanding for how our culture and way of life developed over hundreds and thousands of years.           The Ancient Inca            The Ancient Inca ruled a Southern American empire during the years of 1438 to 1532.  Since the Inca had not created an alphabet or a writing system, there were no written records to inform archaeologists on life of the Inca.  The only records we have are quipus, which the Incas tied knots into a various assortment of different colored strings that kept records.  However, the significance and what they symbolize are unknown to archaeologists.  We must rely on the comparison of ancient artifacts with the historical records of Spaniard's to find evidence of their daily lifestyle and routine.  Although, there is another way to discover this.  The tradition of passing down stories by mouth from generation to generation is another method.  These methods can have flaws though.  Stories are warped over time and can become a false version of the original.  Also, many of the stories of the Inca people were not history or facts, but  it was legends and fables.            The artifacts and corpses of the Inca people may also provide clues.  The position, location, and age all give necessary evidence to discover their meaning to archaeologists.  However, looters and changes over time can tamper with the accuracy of the artifacts.  The archaeologists will collect whatever information they can from the site.  Mountainside sites in particular can harbor a lot of information.  The extreme cold preserve the bodies in the frozen ground.  These specimens can then be X-ray to discover the life they led and cause of death.  But to get to the site is difficult.  Expert mountaineers can reach these high-altitudes with all of the needed gear and return the body to be examined.           The Ancestral Puebloans            The Ancestral Puebloans of Mesa Verde finally stopped their lives of being a nomad, and settled around A.D. 550.  Their former lives of hunting with atlatl and gather transformed to the tradition of farming.  Villages were built and the land on mesa tops were cleared for agriculture.  The new area inspired innovation in their tools, creativity, and architecture.  The Ancestral Puebloans were avid basket makers.  They also created unique pottery and more efficient weapons.  The earliest houses were called Pithouses, which later became Kivas.  These Pithouse were clustered into villages, and communities were formed.  By the year A.D. 750, the population of the Ancestral Puebloans had multipled massively.           The City of Atlantis            The infamous city of Atlantis was rumored to have sunken in the waters off of Southern Greece.  Underwater archaeologists have found it in excellent condition.  The 'Lost City' is more than 5,000 years old, and one of the oldest sunken sites ever.  With the aid of new digital technology, they will be able to explore it.  The city was supposedly sunk by either sea level changes or ground subsidence.  Considering that only one percent of the ocean floor has been explored, this is a major discovery for oceanography.  This was one of the most extraordinary finds.

You might think that these questions are impossible to answer because nobody from the past is alive to tell us what life was like back then. That is not true. An archaeologist could probably answer these questions. Archaeologist, find and interpret information from the past, they study our past life. They travel, dig and search to find old remains. With these remains, such as old clothing, artifacts, and other things they find valuable information and with this information they discover things about the past that no one ever knew about, which in this story was information about the Inca, Puebloans and the Pavlopetri.            Information about the Inca, Puebloans and the Pavlopetri is so important to us because in some cases it teaches us how they communicated or what language they spoke in their day of life. In source 1 we learn that the Inca lived in Peru and they didn't have a formal alphabet or system of writing. So if they didn't use an alphabet or didn't use writing to communicate, what did they use? Archeologist found that the Inca used 'quipus' to keep track of days and to keep track of their livestock. Quipus is simply the knotting of colored string. So before our time where we have, electronics and paper and pencil to communicate, you now know that people used to use knots to communicate. One may not think that this information is important but it shows us how our world is changing.       Although this was the past, it really could affect the way an individual might act. Knowing that life wasn't always easy and and everything was always there we now know that people in the past communicated in many different ways. This is why information about the Inca, Puebloans and the Pavloptri is so important.

What we have learned from the ancient peoples have told us many things about different cultures and how they came to be. Such is the information found about the Inca, the Mesa Verde, and the city of Atlantis. These things could be found helpful with good ways of decrypting the information. The discoveries that have been made about the Inca, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri are so important because they will help us understand more about life in the past. Clues about their religion, art and architecture, agriculture, government, transportation, and way of life will improve our knowledge of the way they used to think and do. It is also important to interpret the artifacts in such accurate ways so we do not carry inaccurate and incorrect information for years and years to come.             Trying to discover about these three people has helped archeologists also learn about geography and where people used to live. It also helps us know how long objects can last and under what conditions such as rain, snow, or sunny summer days. It will help us organize the facts away from the myths and we can go back to written information and discover whether or not they were false.

Lost Civilizations           The Incas, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetris were all apart of the search for lost civilizations.           The Incas               The Incas date back to the time frame of 1438 to around 1532. They were known to have ruled a southern American empire that rivaled the expanse of ancient Rome. Historians know some of the olden stories because of the writings of the Europeans. They had left behind journals and letters. As in many ancient civilizations Inca artifacts might be of object made from stone, pottery, gold, and even silver. Some artifacts are buried with their owner to be with them in the afterlife. The fall of the Incas was easy to date because the Spaniards murdered the Incan king in 1532 and took the Incan empire.               The Puebloans           The first Peubloans date all the way to A.D. 550. They were known for making baskets and for their skills of crafting. They lived in pithouses that were clustered into small villages usually that were built on mesa tops. When it was about 750 A.D. they began to make their houses above ground. During the Classic period (1100 A.D. and 1300 A.D.) the population reached several thousand.   Cliff Dwellers were first reported by a cowboy during the 1800's. They left no written records, yet for all the silence these structured speak with a certain eloquence.               The Pavlopetris                The Pavlopetris city was lost under the waters off of southern Greece enduring myths know as the lost city of Atlantis. The sunken settlements dates back about 5,000 years to the time of Homer's heroes. Dr. Jon Henderson says 'There is now no doubt that this is the oldest submerged town in the world.' He then stated ' It has remains dating from 2800 to 1200 BC, long before the glory days of classical Greece.'The site which straddles around 30,000 square meters of the ocean floor is believed to have been swallowed up by the sea some time around the date of 1000 BC.

Ancient Cities               The ancient cities that have been lost over the years are a great mystery to all of mankind. We find ourselves intruiged to know more about the wonderful civilizations that lived before us so we strive to find little things that connect the puzzle. All of these little things add up to one big thing. That big thing is the lost citie's secrets that people have been awaiting for years. We can find these secrets through curiosity, wonder, and amazment.            The lost city of Inca is a very fascinating place to discover. The Incans had no formal writing system or alphabet. They kept track of livestock and calendars on knotted colorful strings they caled quipus. On the quipus, there are symbols, but because there is no alphabet we know of, we cannot understand what is written on them. There is little left for historians to discover about the Incas. One contribution to this problem is looters. Looters are people who hunt for treasure that may be valuable to them. The only problem with looters other than it is wrong to steal is that they are taking away pieces to a puzzle that we are struggling to understand. Some of the things that we know about the Incas come from stories that we have heard from the spaniards through letters. We have to be cautious though when interpreting these letters because they cannot speak the language well so they may not actually be telling what is written. The other part of what we know comes from objects they left behind. They left textiles and clothing which was mostly preserved becuase of the hot weather, they left bodies on the mountain tops which are frozen becauase of the weather and we are able to bring the bodies down and study them using advanced technology which helps tell us when they died and what happened to them. Though we may not know much, the Inca's way of life is an extraordinary mystery just waiting to be discovered.            Another city waiting to be discovered would be the Puebloans. About 1400 years ago, a civilization of Puebloans flourished for abut 700 years.

The discoveries that have been made about the Inca, the Puebloans and the Pavlopetri are extremely important. These discoveries tell us a lot about the cultures, discoveries, religion, and disappearance of these people. We know many things about each civilization. We know that the Inca have no system of writing or archives for history. They recorded everything in knots in colored strings called quipus. Too record everything in such a way makes some of our accomplishments obsolete. Even now we cannot figure out what the quipus mean.        We know exactly how the Puebloans lived. We know that they lived in pit houses and used atlatl. We would not have known that if we did not discover these artifacts. We also know that some of them were amazing stone masons because they carved their houses into side of the mountains. We have not yet discovered why they made the move into the mountains. We also know that they were very skilled with pottery through the shards that we have found.        We know that the Plavopetri lived in a planed city. This is significant because this is the first planned city that archaeologists have found to date. It was found 40 years ago by a british archaeologist. If he did not discover this then we would not have the wealth of knowledge about the Greeks that we do now. It also offers insights into the Mycenaen society which disapeared without a trace...or so we thought.        These discoveries have added to our stores of knowledge and made us curious. It makes us wonder what else is out there. It makes us ask 'What else could be burried under the sand, or the ground, or in a mountains?' Without asking questions we would know a lot less about the world. Discovering new things leads us to asking new questions. Asking new questions leads us to new answers.

The discoveries of the Inca people,Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri are important because they show what life was like back when they were alive and how it was like to live there. the Inca people kept records by using string. That shows how people used to keep records and how smart people were. They ruled part of South America at one time. Archaeologists found ruins of buildings, and gold and silver, pottery, and artifacts made from stone.         The puebloans for more than 700 years lived in Mesa Verde. Instead of hunting the puebloans farmed and gathered food. they lived in pithouses clustered into small villages built on mesa tops or in cliff recesses. the people learned to make pottery and how to make bow and arrows, and more efficient weapons for hunting than a spear thrower.          The Pavlopteri were important because they found a underwater city. They found buildings, courtyards, main streets, and rock cut tombs, and religious structures. they also found shards of pottery. They found ceramics dating back to the stone age. That is important because you can study the ceramics to see what the tools were like back then and learn some things about them.the site of the city takes up 30,000 square meters of the ocean floor. Dr. Jon Henderson says that there is no doubt that this is the oldest submerged town in the world. It was discovered by a british oceanographer about 40 years ago. It was only this year that marine archaeologists were able properly survey the ruins. They say that the site was never reoccupied. They said that only about one percent of the ocean floor has been explored. That is why they are so important it helps us learn about the past and how it was to live during those times and what they used.

Ancient cilivilizations of the Inca, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri  are important to our world's history. They contributed culture, language, and acrchutechture into our modern day society.                               The Inca had no official language or alphabet but they used methods of knotting strings called quipus to record the calender and to keep count of livestock. The Inca had left clues of religion, art, agriculture, government and transportation. How do we know about the Inca? We know most of what we learn about them from stories or legends being passed down. Some of the stories we know of today come from the Spaniards who did not speak the Inca language but described what they saw. Some artifacts we know of come from the ruins of buildings and graves of the dead. The Inca had lived in the Andes mountains where it was difficult to reach. From what the Inca had done in their civilazation, has contributed to the future. They lived in the mountains, later on, other uses for protection has been used. Language has devolped differntly, art has evolved, transportation and our calender may had follewed a pattern of the Inca as well. Therfore, Inca society has influenced modern day as well.                   The Publoans had influenced society as well but in different ways. The Puebloans lived in pithouses from A.D 550 to A.D 750. Agriculture then began for their civilization. The mesa-top was suitable for farming. They were known for bascket making  and their skill for that craft. From beind nomadic they began to have a more settled life style. They farmed, hunted and gathered. They created weaponds such as the bow and arrow, and for more accuracy the atlatl, a spear thrower. Later on, their population multiplied. They have contributed alot to society by having agriculture, hunting and weapondry. Inconclusion their life style had been used later on as well, people created more advanced weaponds, farming and crafts.                   The lost city is more seen as a lovely scenery to live in. There were courthouses, gardens, courtyards, main streets, shards of pottery and religious sculptures were discovered. Marine geologists are still trying to determine why this city sank. Theories want to show that it sank due to earthquakes, or a tsunami. The site stretches 30,000 square meters above the ocean ground. The sight was founded only forty years ago by a British oceanographer. Therfore, the Lost city had contriuted architecture, landscaping, and crafts to society.                   In conclusion, the three civilizations of the Inca, the Puebloans, and the Pavopetri have influenced the modern day culture of farming, architecture, and crafts. Without these civilizations we might not have had the arts and buildings we have today.

The Past       Have you ever wondered what the past was like? How we       developed into what we are now? Well I have, and that is why I       am typing this report so I can tell you all about it.       To begin with, I would like to tell you about the ancient       Inca of Peru. Surprising, they did not have a formal alphabet or       system of writing. Instead they made knots in colored strings to       record the calendar and to keep count of their livestock. The       first Europeans to meet the Inca were amazed at their system of        quipus. How did they run such a large empire with just strings to       keep records. No one today even knows what the knots mean.       Since we have little record about the Inca most of what we       know comes from stories that were passed from generation to       generation. We only know some stories though because the       Europeans who arrived in the empire described the Inca in       diaries and letters. The rest of our knowledge comes from       artifacts and other things they may have left behind such as       pottery, gold, silver, or clothing.       Secondly, I would like to explain to you the history of the       ancient Puebloans. Mesa Verde National Park has a great       reminder of the culture. These ancient people have been called       the Anasazi or 'the ancient ones', Puebloans or 'village       dwellers', or Cliff Dwellers. They are also known as       Basketmakers because they have a skill for crafting. Agriculture       began to replace hunting and gathering and they lived in small       villages and sometimes in cliff recesses.  Also Pithouses       became very popular buildings and their population multiplied.       These people were excellent at building, they were very crafty,       and they were skillful.       Lastly, I would like to inform you about the Lost Greek       city. The secrets of this lost city may have inspired one of the       world's most enduring myths.  The fable of Atlantis has been       brought to light beneath the waters off southern Greece. It has       been explored by many archaeologist and marine geologists.  It       dates back to 5,000 years. It is thought to believe that is is the       oldest submerged town in the world and it was there long before       the classical Greece. Atlantic takes up about 30,00 square meter       of ocean floor and was consumed into the sea about 1000 BC.        Well I told you that I would tell you about the past and I       have. No longer do you have to wonder what it was like and       how we got to where we are. This report told you everything       you needed to know and more. Did you learn as much as I did?

The first Eropeans to meet the Inca were amazed that they could run huge empire using strings to keep records . The ancient Inca of Peru had no formal alphabet or system of writing . By studying these clues, archaeolojists andothers can piece together details of Inca life . Some of the old stores were written by Eropeans who arrived in the empire in 1532 . The ones that would go visit were Spanish soldiers and priest . The Apaniards did notspeak the inca language well . They may not have understood what the Inca told them, so their desacriptions might not be accurate . As in many ancient civilizations, Inca artifacts might be objects made from stone,pottery,gold or silver . Some artifacts turn up in the ruins of buildings . Some treasures were taken centuries ago, but looting still goes on today . They provived the best idea of all about life inperu before and during Inca rule . They write down and photograph any artifacts they find, and note the exact positions in whick they find them. Sometimes archeology confirms historical record . Tell fall of the Inca is easy to date because the Spaniards murdered the last Inca king in 1532 and tookover the empire . The area where they lived hadlong been inhabited by differnent peoples . this has halped to preserve the sites, because looters cannot easily get to them . But it also makes the job of the archaeologists are expert mountains . They have to carry all their equipment up a mountain before they can start to work . Anything they find has to be carried down the mountain for a study . The coldmountains act like a gaint freezer .   Then in the late A.D, 1200s, in the span of a generation or two, they left their homes and moved away . They learned to make pottery and acquired the bow and arrow,a more efficient weapon for hunting than the atlatl, a spear thrower .   They built the houses one against another in long curving rows,often with a pithouse or two in frint . Farming accounted for more of their diet than before, and much mesa-top land was clearded foragriculture .

Archaeology                 There have been many import discoveries all over the world. There are three important discoveries on lost civilizations. Those are: The Incas, The Puebloans, and The Pavlopetri.Each civilization is important in their own way.             The Inca discovery was important because we can learn their ways of life. It is important to know their ways of life because we can use their mentality of union to unify ourselves. We can also learn how the Incas died. It is important to learn how the Incas died because we can prevent our death by eliminating the possibility that we will die like they did. We can learn about the rules they used to control society. It is important to know the rules they used to control society because we might be able to use the same rules.              The Puebloans civilization discovery was important because we can learn from their skill and craft. It would be nice if we could establish their skill of crafting because they aquired the bow and arrow. Their civilization discovery is also important because we can learn, but improve, their architectural ways. The Puebloans were great architects. They had great buildings that we could use now. This discovery was also important because we could use nature at our advantage like they did. If we used nature better we might be able to get more out of it.             The Palvopetri discovery was important because it was the oldest submerged town in the world. There were older sunken sites but none were so pre-planned. It was also important because of its uniqueness. In terms of size and wealth it was extremely unique. It is also important because it was most likely to be considered a a planned civilization. The fact that this was a planned civilization explains that the Palvopetri people were smart perfectionists.               All discoveries have been important. These three are some of the most important discovered civilizations yet.The Incas Civilization was important for its ways of life. The Puebloans was important for its skill and craft. The Palvopetri was important for being the oldest submerged civilization.

The Discoveries of the Civilizations                  Throughout the years, many discoveries have been made about the ancient Inca, Puebloens, and Pavlopetri civilizations. The discoveries range from the discoveries of ancient temples to pieces of broken pottery. These can portray ideas of religion, government, languages, and ways of lifestyle. These items can help archeologists to learn about their life, and in turn, our past.                 The Incan civilization has many different artifacts which have helped archeologists learn about our past and attract tourists alike. The scientists can use the information collected from the artifacts to learn about other civilizations as well. Tourists can improve a country's wealth and cultural diversity. The Incas and their architecture, art, and government system can draw tourists and archeologists alike.                                                                                                                                                                  The Pueblo civilization contains many important artifacts. These range from primitive pithouses to weaving tables. The weaving tables can show us how clothing looked and was made during that time. The pithouses showed us that they should not take over makeover jobs. These people have many different interesting ways of life, and their artifacts help us to learn more about them.                  The Pavlopetri people had many interesting artifacts in their sunken city, the fabled 'Atlantis.' Its remains show the architecture, arts, tools, and lifestyle of Greece before the Classical Era. These include pottery, temples, tombs, and more. All of these different items make up this fascinating archeological dig.                  The different items in the three civilizations varied widely, but their purpouse to us was always the same; to help us learn of our past. From the pithouses of the Pueblo to the Pavlopetri pottery, each artifact tells a story. Every arifact is unique, and they are truly really neat.

The first Puebloans that lived there were know as the basketmakers. They lived in pithouses.        The lost Greek city was also very important to discover. It remained from 2800-1200 B.C and covers 30,000 square meters of the ocean floor. The exploration revealed a world of buildings, courtyards, main streets, and religious structures. They found a possible megaron, and that suggests that the town was a previous elite. Marine geologists thought the settlement sank because of an earthquake of tsunami.

Over the years, many ancient civilizations have been discovered. All though they may not be the same group of people, or have the same story, they all have one thing in common- they all contain important information on why we are who we are today. These civilizations contain facts about how we as humans have grown physically, and mentally. Although it may not be easy to find, these ancient cities have more information than we can see.                                    First, much of what we know about the people of these ancient cities had been found in simple pieces of clay, stone, or even rocks. For example, the Incas people left some pieces of stone, pottery, gold, and silver. They also found these items in the graves.  This might tell us that they used those items daily, so they possibly made their homes out of them. Also, finding those items in the graves could mean they believed in an afterlives. For another example, the Puebloans were found to have houses of stone, discovered with ruins of stacked stone. Also, some baskets that were found reveal that because they did not use pottery, they did not pay much attention to craft. There are so many things found in only a piece of stone sometimes.                                                                                                                                                  Secondly, a large portion of what we learn from past cities is from stories and sights passed down through the generations. For example, the Puebloans were the first cliff dwellers, but we know this because the cowboys told stories of them to the people. For another example, archeologists often check with the Spaniards for what they know about the Incas from their ancestors, possibly by telling stories or myths. Also, the Lost city has always been known as 'Atlantis', and this was a story that has never been confirmed until recently. Stories and myths play a large part in unlocking the past of ancient civilizations.               Finally, sometimes geography helps us learn more of the cities we know little about. For example, the waters surrounding the lost city in Greece have helped to move the sand and reveal artifacts. For the Inca, the cold mountain tops and cliffs have prevented the looters from taking and ruining history to be discovered and preserving the information for archaeologists. geography plays a large part in our history that is being discovered.               Lastly, it is all because of these many things that we know where we come from and how we have learned to adapt and grow. Without the information we have learned from ancient cities such as the Puebloans, the Inca, and the Lost City, we would not understand why things are the way they are today. We cannot learn anything more without the help of our past relatives.

Information from the past to learn about how we are affected by it now.  If we do not have our facts right about the past we cannot advance toward the future.  We absorb this culture to learn about what we could use to advance now.  We can use this knowledge to learn better ways of surviving and living.  With their information we can use it to plan our future, and how Earth has changed.  With this we can see how we have changed and can change.       Ancient Inca:  Archaeology Unlocks the Secrets of the Past   The Inca was a tribe who inspite having a weird way of running government and economics they survived.  Their artifacts that were left, had barely been damaged due to their environment.  This helps us learn how our environment has a great effect on us.  The Spaniards came and wrote about them.  These newcomers to this land they have never seen before was odd, because they could not understand the Inca.  These two types of people were different from eachother and on two different levels in technology.  Stories about the Inca were passed down from generation to generation.  The stories lived on and on, even after the loss.  The Inca were took over by the Spaniards.  The Spaniards killed their king.  We now know how we have advanced from doing things like that.  Killing enisent tribes would now be thought of as 'not right'.  This shows how we have changed to more civil people.       Mesa Verde National Park Ancestral Puebloans and Their World   Before the Europeans came their were different people living here than we have today.  They were called Ancestral Puebloans.  They are knowns as Basketmakers.  This is different from how it is today, because we mostly have machines do all the work.  They lived on mesa tops. They have pithouses, it was a house that sunk in the ground and was almost like our houses today.  The houses evolved to kivas.  That shows how much change is happening and how it is forming to today.  They later started building them above ground just like most people today.  Their population was increasing and they were evolving in technology as well.  They went from pole-and-adobe construction to stone masonry.  The population was getting out of hand so some people were moving back to the place that sheilded their ancestors.  Researches may use this information to help deal with problems of today like immigration and other problems that may cause population issues.  Then drasticly almost all of the Ancestral Puebloans moved back to the place where their ancestors lived.  Soon the place was deserted and almost no Ancestral Puebloans lived at the place they left.  Researchers could not find the information about why they had left that place.  They guessed maybe it was resource, social, political problems, or maybe they look for new opportunity. Explanitory Article: Why were the discoveries that have been made about the Inca, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri so important?       By Clay Martin       Over the years, archaeologists have made several amazing discoveries about our world from the past. Some of these discoveries, for example, are the discoveries of the Inca, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri civilizations. We can learn and discover many things about ourselves and these people from the artifacts we find in their homes. These civilizations are obviously very important. In my opinion, the reason that they are most important is that they can teach us about both ourselves and them.       The Inca are one of these amazing civilizations. Through artifacts, we have learned that they used colored strings called quipus to record things. We have learned that they were defeated by the Europeans in 1532. We have learned that they had one of the largest empires ever. All of these facts were discovered because of artifacts.       The Puebloans are another great civilization. They lived in Pithouses. They invented the bow and arrow. They were known as the basketmakers. We have learned all these facts because of artifacts.       A third civilization in this group is the Pavlopetri. Archaeologists have discovered that they lived in Atlantis. They've discovered that Atlantis is the oldest planned town ever. They've been able to come up with theories of how Atlantis was destroyed, such as sea level changes, an earthquake, or a tsunami. Again, these discoveries came from artifacts.       There is a lesson to be learned from these artifacts and discoveries. Although these civilizations were amazing, they all have one thing in common: they made mistakes. They weren't perfect. There isn't, never has been, and never will be a perfect civilization. But if we learn from the mistakes of those who came before us, we will be able to become more perfect. There is only one way for us to become more perfect: if people work together and honor and respect one another.

Lost Civilazations       Part 1.   Source #1.   The ancient Inca had no formal alphebet or system of writing. The Inca made knots in colored string to record the calender to keep count of livestock. Today no one knows what the knots mean. A lot of the knowledge comes from the artifacts left behind, and from the sites in which the artifacts were found. Archeologists found stone, pottery, gold, and silver. They also found Ince textiles and clothing. Some Inca sites have been disturbed by treasure hunters or looters. The Spaniards murdered the last Inca king in 1532 and took over the empire. The Inca lived high in the Andes and may have even worshipped some mountain peeks.   Source #2.   About 1,400 years ago a group of people living in the Four Corners region chose Mesa Verde for their home. For more than 700 years they and their descendants lived and flourished here, eventually building elaborate stone communities in the sheltered alcoves of the canyon walls. Then, in the late A.D. 1200s, in the span of a generation or two, they left their homes and moved away.Farming replaced hunting and gathering as their main livelihood. they lived in pithouses clustered into small villages usually built on mesa tops but sometimes in cliff recesses. They used bow and arrow for hunting.   Source #3.   The sunken settlement dates back some 5000 years ago. The site is believed to be consumed by the ocean.       Part 2.   Archeologists find artifacts which help them to discover what happened to the lost civilizations. But sometimes the artifacts dont always survive.

Long ago the ancient civilizations of the Inca, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri bustled with life. Now as archeologists take a closer look inside the lives of these people, we could learn more about these people than we ever imagined we would.        First, the archaeologists climbed high up into the Rocky Mountains so that they could explore the ruins of the Inca. They found that to keep records they tied complex knots, no one know exactly what they mean though. They also found old cups, bowls and other stone or metal objects like jewelry. These findings help one to try and understand how these items were made and what they might have been used for. They also discovered bodies that are so well preserved that they could use modern medicine to figure out how that individual died.        Then, archeologists traveled to Mesa Verde, the ancient city in which the Puebloans used to exist. They found odd huts, called a pit house. These houses where supported by four corner timbers and had a fire pit with an air deflector. The people then graduated to adobe house, which were stronger. Their pottery also changed, instead of having dull gray pots, they used elaborated black and white drawings.          The archeologists then went to Greece, just off the coast to explore the sunken settlement of the Pavlopetri. It is said that the civilization sunk about five thousand years ago and no one is absolutely sure how it can to be under water. While there, archeologists explore a world of buildings, from courtyards to tombs. This city was covered in shards of broken pottery. This civilization is a wonderful mystery that no one is quite sure about, but if we keep searching we might find an even bigger surprise.        Exploring ancient civilizations like the Inca, Puebloans, and the Pavlovian is important because it teaches one about the history of these amazingly smart people.

The discovery of ancient civilizations have served as a key to understanding the human race's past.  The findings from the Incas, Puebloans, and Pavlopetri, give archaeologists an idea of their lives and culture.  The discoveries also show how far in relation we are with our past brethren.  Archaeological findings are doors that lead us into the past.       One civilization was the Incas.  The Incas were natives to Peru, and lived high up in the Andes Mountains.  The artifacts found have allowed us to see the Incas culture.  We learned that they worshiped many gods, practiced blood sacrifices, and had a craving in poetry.  Archaeologists have learned another civilization through the mere discoveries of artifacts.  The Incas however, are considered a lost civilization.  There demise  is apparent through the findings of a hand full of Spanish records.  The Spaniards over all led to the ending of the once great civilization.  This shows the the finally to the the Incas.       The Pavlopetri's town is what must have inspired the myth of Atlantis.  The town is submerged in the waters off the coast of southern Greece.  The city is still intact, as if it was built underwater, and artifacts still remain.  This shows how real life events can be transformed into a well known myth.  There are many theories that surround how this city came to be underwater.  The main theory seems to be that the change in water levels is what lead to the town's condition.  The Pavlopetri were a distant group that inspired the myth of Atlantis.      The Puebloans were a group of native Americans who lived in the Four Corners Region.  The civilization created well designed stone communities in which they could keep cool within their houses.  This shows the innovation within the past humans.   The Puebloan had a huge change within their lifestyle. They went from nomadic to living in small villages.   This shows the major change.       The findings from archaologists help us lead into the past.  The Incas, the Pavlopetris, and the Puebloans all consist of this group.  The inovation of our past can easily compare with the technology of today.  We can better understand the pats through the discovery of acient artifacts.

The Inca was a tribe that made a bunch of stuff that we use today. Like pottery and ways to hunt animals and use them for food or clothes. We have discovered a bunch of artifacts. This also teaches us what they used to do in the before time. They didn't have a formal alphabet or system of writing. To keep track of the calendar, they made knots with colorful strings called quipus. But nobody today knows how to use those strings.        For more than 700 years, the puebloans lived here at mesa verde national park. Then, in the late A.D. 1200s, they left their homes and moved away. Mesa Verde National Park reminds us a lot about this culture. The first ancestral puebloans settled at Mesa Verde about A.D. 550. They are known as basketmakers for their skill at the craft. Farming replaced hunting and gathering as their main livelihood. They lived in pithoises clustered into small villages usually built on mesa tops but sometimes in cliff recesses.        By A.D. 1000 the people of Mesa Verde had advanced from pole-and-adobe construction to skillful stone masonry. Pottery also changed, from simple designs on a dull gray background to black drawings on a white background. Between A.D. 1100 and A.D.1300, during the Classic Period, the population may have reached several thousand. It was mostly concentrated in compact villages of many rooms, often with the kivas built inside the enclosing walls rather than out in the open.
