Discoveries made at archaeological site are vital to the human species because we have a thirst for knowledge, and with that comes the need to know what happened before us and before written records. Sites like the Inca villages in the Andes Mountains, the cliff dwellers in Mesa Verde, and the sunken city of Pavlopetri all give historians clues to our unknown past and the secrets of yesterday's world. These discoveries are important to us for many reasons, and to feed our natural curiosity, we have traveled the globe, searching for long lost clues to our past.            The artifacts discovered at Inca sites are vital towards finding out the truth of our history. The resources the Incas had at their disposal, such as gold and silver, tells us how they viewed precious metals. The abundance of the metals in Inca society made them less valuable almost, and that viewpoint changes the way historians portray ancient Inca.            The Ancestral Pueblo-ans, who lived in Mesa Verde about 1,400 years ago, originally were nomads, but settled down along canyon walls for about seven centuries. Archaeologists know they flourished, due to the way the soil and ground around the abandoned homes is. The Pueblo-ans show historians how people lived, worked, and died in North America in a portion of the Four Corners.            The Pueblo-ans also resided on cliffs, and soon became known as cliff dwellers. Their advanced masonry told historians that there were some advancements in their society that we did not know were there at all. The remains of both of the Pueblo-ans dwellings exhibit their way for life, the resources they used, how they used those resources, advantages to their territory, and disadvantages to their homes.            Once the lost Greek city of Pavlopetri was found off the coast of southern Greece, archaeologists were all over it, claiming it to be the largest planned submerged city to be discovered so far. The artifacts found on this huge, sunken site are important for our search for the truth. It not only raises more questions on the myth of Atlantis, but it also answers a few too. Archaeologists have been able to date Pavlopetri back to around the time Plato described Atlantis, and the architecture and advancement in buildings and artifacts fits in almost perfectly with Plato's observations of the fabled Atlantis. Some wonder if Pavlopetri is actually the sunken city Plato was referring to, and if it is, what happened? Once again, our natural curiosity and thirst for knowledge takes over and we must know what actually went down at that time in history.           Human beings have a natural hunger for knowledge, and knowing how things happened, why they happened, when the happened, and who they happened to in the past has lead the way for our brains and instincts to find the answers. the discoveries made in the ruins of ancient Inca, the remains of an abandoned civilization in Mesa Verde, and the subterranean mystery in southern Greece all contribute to our understanding of the past and, in some ways, our future.

The discoveries of the Incas, Puebloans, and Atlantis have been of great importance because they have affected the way society is today.  These civilizations have left clues that have led historians and archeologists to piece together the lifestyles of these three ancient societies.             The ancient Incas had no formal writing system which made it quite difficult for archeologists to study.  Still, archeologists  were able to learn about their culture through the artifacts found such as textiles and clothing that have survived for the long lengths of time. To learn as much information as they do, they need to keep careful records.  To learn more information,  archeologists can compare with other scientists and come up with an explanation.  It is important for scientists to study the history of this civilization so our society can learn from it and not repeat it.            Discoveries from the first ancestral Puebloans in Mesa Verde make it possible to improve our society's skill and craftsmanship.    Archeologists have learned much about their tools and livelihood.  Production factories can make improvements of these tools and therefore advance in technology.             The secrets of the lost city of Atlantis has allowed scientists to research the field of natural disaster and Earth's movement. The myths of the city have sparked archeologist's interest and now they have been able to research the sunken settlement and find that it was once possibly a lively city.  This extraordinary myth has been able to keep underwater exploration going and has given archeologists the opportunity to survey the rest of the ocean floor.           The findings of the Inca, Puebloans, and Pavlopetri have been so important as to exploring the old civilizations and improving new ones.  Archeologists have reasearched artifacts, structures, and stories that allow us citizens to think of our daily lives and work to advance in society.

Archeologists have found many different artifacts and ruins from the ancient times. Each piece of evidence fitting into the puzzle. Some artifacts were oral, such as stories and legends that were passed down from generation to generation.Some stories were passed down by being written.They were written down by the Europeans who arrivedin the empire in 1532. Maybe that skill got them making their own homes out of straw. As they learned to make pottery, and learned about the bow and arrow, they made a better weapon for hunting. As the Puebloans learned to build, they started making their homes from poles that stood upright and mud. Later on, some stone homes were found suggesting that the were advancing in technology. It also shows that they were constantly finding something better to make their homes out of.          The lost city of atlantis has been found. Since it was found beneath the waters of southern Greece, archeologists have inferred that the city, when still up, was near southern Greece. The sunken civilization dates back some 5,000 years to the time of Homer's heroes. Their are some remains that date from 2800 to 1200 BC. Archeologists have also found that some ceramics date back to the end of the stone age. It suggests that the settlement was occupied some 5,000 years ago. Archaeologists study historical artifacts in order to learn of Earth's past. By studying ancient artifacts, archaeologists have discovered signs of ancient civilizations. Three major discoveries by paleontologists are the Incas, Puebloans, and the lost Greek city.             The Inca civilization lasted from 1438-1532. The Incas lived in Peru and had no formal alphabet or writing system. The only way we reason we know of their existence is through artifacts and oral history. Archaeologists can piece together details of Inca life by  studying the Inca artifacts left behind. The Inca civilization isn't the only civilization historians know about.            The ancient Puebloans lived about 1,400 years ago. They were formerly nomadic, but they began a settled life. Their old hunting and gathering ways were replaced by farming. They lived for more than 700 years in Mesa Verde.  They are known for their skill at the craft of basket making. For an unknown reason, they migrated to cliff alcoves.            Beneath the waters off southern Greece, divers discovered a sunken settlement. The settlement dates back about 5,000 years ago in Homer's heroes time. According to Dr. Jon Henderson, this is the oldest submerged town in the world. The site is 30,000 square meters large, and it is believed to have been consumed by the sea around 1000 BC. Many theories of how the city sunk include sea level changes, tsunami, and ground subsidence as the result of earthquakes.             Archaeologists have discovered many artifacts of Earth's past, but there are still numerous more things to be found. For example, less than 1% of the world's ocean floors have ever been surveyed. The Incas, Puebloans, and the lost Greek city are only a few discoveries in the large Earth.

Ancient Inca and the Puebloans are important today because they unlock secrets of the past.  Archaeologists have been studying how Inca and Puebloans have been discovered from different clues left behind and different kinds of research.  Inca left clues about their art and architecture, agriculture, government, transportation, and way of life. Puebloans have been famous for their skill at the craft, they were known as Basketmakers.           Ancient Inca used quipus to record calendars to keep a count of livestock.  The world know some stories about Inca from the passing of stories from generation to generation and also because of the old stories written down by the Europeans who arrived in the empire in 1532.  Inca artifacts have been discovered from the ruins of buildings and others are found buried in graves for the dead to use in the afterlife.  Inca textiles and clothing have been preserved in the dry deserts on Peru's coasts or the cold mountains of the Andes.  The Inca sites were disturbed by looters or treasure hunter, who take anything that might be valuable.          Puebloans were also called Anasazi also known as 'the ancient ones' or 'ancient enemies'.  Like most civilizations, hunting and gathering were their main livelihood until it got replaced with farming.  Puebloans lived in pit houses that were usually built on mesa tops but sometimes in cliff recesses. Pithouses didn't last long until A.D. 750 that evolved into kivas.  Puebloans use of baskets declined because of the widespread use of pottery.  A major population shift was when the people began to move back into the cliff alcoves.  Kivas were used for healing rites or to pray for rain, luck in hunting, or a good crop.  Mesa Verde was deserted due to drought and crop failures.  Pueblo people, and maybe other tribes, are descendants of the Ancestral Puebloans of Mesa Verde.          Archaeologists studied these ancient civilizations not only for the enjoyment, but for the history of it.  Today we the people would know nothing about our the past life of how people lived without all this technology and advancement.  Both of the civilizations used their natural resources to uncover their daily life.

Some information archaeologists know come from oral history, o stories passed from generation to generation. Passing stories was a very important way to preserve a communities history. Other ways archaeologists know information is from artifacts. Some Inca artifacts may be made of stone, pottery, gold, or silver. These materials last for a long time, even if buried for years. They can be found in the ruins of buildings, or in graves for the use of the afterlife. Some information may be hard to identify because of looters. Looters rob the artifacts from places, making it hard for archaeologists to study the life of the Inca.

Ancient History           By: Chas Dowtin       Throughout history humans have passed down information about the time that   once was in the form of stories, pictures, and relics.  Some people say that discoveries made about that time are irellevant as now us in the modern era have no need to study these primitive civilization, but these people have not thought to consider the benefits.  These ancient civilizations can help us to piece together the history of our world.  With this information we could improve our world and the lives of the people in it. These civilizations should not be taken for granted because of their major contribution to the world.       An excellent example of a civilization like these is the Inca.  The discoveries about   this civilization  have helped expand the world's knowledge of exploration in South America.  We learned of the type of clothing they wore, what food they ate, and where they lived. Using the knowledge we can figure out what was the lifestyle of the Inca was liek before the Spanish invaded.  Most of what we knwo about the Inca we had learned from spanish accounts as the Inca had no written language and kept track of all their data using colored strings alled quipis.  By cross refrencing the remains of these places with their oral history and written accounts Archeologists have been able to find mout new information about the Inca. These new facts have helped weave together the Inca's part in the tapestry of history.       Two other important civilizations are the Puebloans and the Pavlopetri. These both   provide information about their homelands. The Puebloans are a North American civilization that lived in the the south west deserts. This civilization has helped us learn about the cliff dwelling civilizatioon which are the descendants if the Puebloans. This has solved a mystery people have been trying to answer for years. The Pavlopetri were a Greek civlization which was submerged under the sea. This city can explain the rumors of the mythical city of Atlantis. This also solves a large mystery in recorded history. Both these civlizatiosn have helped to clear the fog of history so that we can see the truth.       All civlizations discovered have donated to historians world wide helping them fill   in the blanks in history. The Inca, Puebloan, and Pavlopetri all have made major contributions to world hsitory. We should protect and study these sites along with others to protect the tales that they hold.

The discoveries of all of these lost civilizations are important to history. It may fill in holes where something was not known, tell about the daily lives of the people that lived there, or it may just contribute to information already known.           The ancient empire of the Incas ruled for almost one-hundred years, but was then overthrown by the Spaniards. The origin of the Incas is completely unknown. Along with where they came from, their daily lifestyles are also not known well. What we know the most about is their stories, tools, and how they were overthrown. When archaeologists found the remains of an ancient Inca civilization, some new things were learned. They had worshiped some of the mountain peaks around them and they found what is called a quipus. It was used to keep track of days and many other things.           An ancient people known as Ancestral Puebloans inhabited an area called Mesa Verde. They had lived there for more than seven-hundred years then left everything they had and moved somewhere else. Where and why they moved is still unknown to archaeologists, but because they left all of their belongings behind, they could still learn about how they lived. They were mostly farmers but they would also hunt. The main weapon they used was the bow and arrow, which was more efficient than the atlatl, a spear thrower. The first lived in dug-out houses but then eventually moved to the cliffs. They only lived in cliffs for about one-hundred years before they disappeared. The only reason that archaeologists think that these people left is because there was a drought at about the same time.            In southern Greece, archaeologists found a sunken settlement that dates back about five-thousand years. It is the oldest submerged town in the world. How this settlement sank is still not known but  it is assumed that it is because of either sea level changes, ground subsidence or both. This settlement is thought to be the one that inspired the Atlantis myth. Not all of it has been searched yet, but entire buildings and courtyards have been discovered.            All of these discoveries are important to history. They give us insight to many ancient civilizations. We learn about the past about the people before us and where some of the myths and legends may have come from. To sum it all up, these discoveries teach us about ancient lifestyles, religions and the origin of legends.

The Inca, Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri. All ancient civilizations that, believe it or not, have shaped our world to this day. As we keep discovering artifacts and information about these civilizations, we are able to further understand how they have effected are lives and why they are no longer with us.   To start off, the Inca tribe was a civilization for nearly a hundred years (1438-1532) that ruled a South American empire that rivaled the expansion of ancient Rome. Today we have been able to find artifacts, items that these people have left behind, to piece together a grand picture of the Inca religion, art and architecture, agriculture, government, transportation, and way of life. We can also thank the art of story telling for what we know today about this civilization. Stories passed down from generation to generation were an important way to preserve history back then. 'We know some of the old stories because they were written down by the Europeans who arrived in the empire in 1532. The visitors were Spanish soldiers and priests. They described the Inca in letters and diaries.' A quote from Beth Bruber's Acient Inca: Archaeology unlocks the Secrets of the Past. Bruber also states that 'the most importnat things to learn about a civilization are where it came from and what happened to it.' The fall of the Inca tribe was due to the Spaniards murdering the last Inca king in 1532 and taking over the empire. To find out the origin of the Inca, archaeologists use some of the most advanced technigues in the world. Using aerial photography can help them see things such as patterns in ancient monuments,that they cannot see from the ground. This is also a good technique becuase the Inca lived high up in the Andes mountains, making the job of a archarologist much more difficult. From the Inca civilization we are even able to see bodies and learn about how these people lived, and how they died.   Now moving on to the Puebloans. About 1,400 years ago a group of people living in the Four Corners  region chose Mesa Verde as their home. For over 700 years these people flourished here, eventually building elaborate communities, but then in the late A.D 1200s, generations left and moved away. Today Mesa Verde National Park preserves a spectacular reminder of this ancient culture. From the first being known as Basketmakers for their skill at the craft to the ancestral Puebloans being kniown as cliff dwellers, as that is where they lived. Through drout and crop failures,socail and political probllems, the people simply wanted to look for new opportunities elssewhere. Today we still do not know the exact story of these people, but 'whatever may have happened,some of today's Pueblo people,andmaybe other tribes, aredescendants of the Ancestral Puebloans of Mesa Verde.' a quote from Roy Anderson's Mesa Verde National Park Ancestral Puebloans and Their World.    Finally the Lost Greek city. Could this be the city that may have unspired the Atlantis myth? Beneath the water off sourthern Greece there is a site of sunken settlement covering 30,000 square meters of the ocean floor. only this year were marine archaeologists able to properly ssurvey the ruins with digital technology. it revealed a wrold of buildings, courtyeards,main streets, rock-cut tombs,and religious stuctures. These artifacts opened up a whole other world of exploration. We could now see this once prospering city come to life again. Marine geologists have yet to work out why this settlement sank. ''It is signifact because as a submerged site it was never reoccupied.'' said elias spondylis, co-directer of the surveyand head of Greece'sunderwater antiquities department. Although there is much more to be found under the water this represents a frozen moment of the past.   Overall, all three of these civilizations that once propered as we do today are very important as each and everyday we are able to extend our knowledge with knew artifacts and information. should we be questioning our fate? what will happen to our mondern world civilization? Is it already crumbling beneath our feet?

The first Ancestral Puebloans settled in Mesa Verde (Spanish for 'green table') about A.D. 550. They are known as Basketmakers for their skill at the craft. Formerly nomadic, they were beginning to lead a more settled way of life. Farming replaced hunting and gathering as their main livelihood. They lived in pithouses clustered into small villages usually built on Mesa tops but sometimes in cliff recesses. They learned to make pottery and acquired the bow and arrow, a more efficient weapon for hunting than the atlatl, a spear thrower. These were fairly prosperous times for the Basketmakers, and their population multiplied. About A.D. 750 they began building houses above ground, with upright walls made of poles and mud. Pueblo people, and maybe other tibes, are descendants of the Ancestral Puebloans of Mesa Verde.

The Incas, Puebloans, and Greeks. These are some ancient civilizations that have thrived throughout the world. We know much about these people and their ways of life, but how? Through discoveries ranging from ceramic pots to sunken cities, we have obtained the knowledge needed to describe these groups.       The Inca had no formal alphabet or writing systems, so how do we know what we know? They left behind clues. Portraits were left behind by the Inca showed of their religion, agriculture, government, transportation, and way of life. Oral stories have also been passed down from generation to generation, preserving a community's culture.   Stories written by early Europeans have also been found. Inca textile and clothing survived remarkably as well, thanks to the Peru's dry deserts.       About 1,400 years ago, the civilization know as the Puebloans chose Mesa Verde as their home. The first Puebloans were leading a 'more settled way of life'. Their first homes, pithouses, were shelters containing a firepit with air deflector, an antechamber containing storage bins or pits, and an entrance the home located at the top. Many of the Puebloans were skilled a weaving baskets and other useful items. By A.D. 1000, these people had advanced from basic construction to skillful stone masonry.       The myth of the Greek city, Atlantis, has been told many times over the years, but all it is is a myth. Marine geologists have used the information, however, to learn about and discover a sunken city. Off the coast of the Greek city Neapolis, the submerged city was discovered and its roots were amazingly traced back to some 1,200 years ago. Ceramic were found dating back to the stone age. This suggested that the settlement was occupied almost 5,000 years ago! The biologists have researched the 9,000 square meter city.

The Lost Civilizations                          First, im going to talk about the Ancient Incas. The Incas are from Peru and they had no formal alphabet or system of writing. The Inca mad knots in colored strings called quipus to record the calendar to keep a count of livestock. The first Europeans to meet the Inca were amazed thay they could run a huge empire using strings to keep records. Archaeologists have found many ancient quipus but today no one knows what the knots mean. Without anyone being able to read the knots the Incas is more like a big mystery.             Many people find lost ruins fascinating. The fact that the ruins are really old many people wanna exlpore how the Inca lived. Some of what we know about the Inca comes from oral history, or stories passed from generation to generation. Passing on the stories was an important way to preserve a community's history. The visitors who met the Inca were Spanish soldiers and priests. They described the Inca in letters and diaries. Historians have to be careful when they interpret these accounts. The Spaniards did not speak the Inca language well. The rest of our knowledge of the Inca comes from artifacts that were left behind by the Inca. Archaeologists can compare what they learn from artifacts and sites with the Spaniard's accounts of the Inca. Among the most important things to learn about a civilization are where it came from and what happened to it.             About 1,400 years ago, long before Europeans explored North America, a group of people living in the Four Corners region chose Mesa Verde for their home. The first Ancestral Puebloans settled in Mesa Verde about A.D. 550. They are known as Basketmakers for their skill at the craft. Farming replaced hunting and gathering as their main livelihood. They lived in pithouses clustered into small villages usually built on mesa tops.             These were fairly prosperous times for the Basketmakers, and their population multiplied. About A.D. 750 they began building their own houses above ground with upright walls made of poles and mud. The people of Mesa Verde had advanced from pole-and-adobe construction to skillful stone masonry. Pottery also changed, from simple designs on a dull gray background to black drawings on a white background. Farming accounted for more of their diet than before. About A.D. 1200, another major population shift saw people begin to move back into the cliff alcoves that sheltered their ancestors centuries before.              The Cliff Dwellers is next on my list. Ever since local cowboys first reported the cliff dwellings in the 1800s, archaeologists have sought to understand these people's lives. We will never know the whole story: they left no written records and much that was important in their lives has perished. Yet for all their silence, these structures speak with a certain eloquence. The structures are evidence of a society that, over centuries, accumulated skills and traditions and passed them on from generation to generation. Based on modern Pueblo practice, Ancestral Puebloans may have used kivas for healing rites or to pray for rain, luck in hunting, or a good crop. Kivas were gathering places and sometimes also places to weave. Pilasters supported a beam-and- mud roof. Entry was by ladder through a hole in the center of the roof.               Using nature to advantage, Ancestral Puebloans built their dwellings beneath the overhanging cliffs. Their basic construction material was sandstone thay they shaped into rectangualar blocks about the size of a loaf of bread. The motar between the blocks was a mix of mud and water. Rooms averaged about six feet by eight feet, space enough for two or three persons. Isolated rooms in the rear and on the upper levels were generally used for storing crops. Underground kivas, ceremonial chambers, were built in front of the rooms. The kiva roofs created open courtyards where many daily routines took place. Ancestral Puebloans lived in the cliff dwellings for less than 100 years. By about A.D. 1300, Mesa Verde was deserted. Several theories offer reasons for their migration. We know that the last quarter of the A.D. 1200s saw drought and crop failures but these people had survived earlier droughts. Maybe after hundreds of years of intensive use the land and its resources soils, forests, and animals were depleted. Perhaps there were social and political probles, and the people simply looked for new opportunities elsewhere.                A diver explores the sunken settlement beneath the waters of southern Greece. The diver is exploring a myth called Atlantis. The secrets of a lost city that may have inspired one of the world's most largest search. The sunken settlement dates back some 5,000 years to the time of  Homer's heroes. There is no doubt that Atlantis is the oldest submerged town in the world. The remains are from 2800 to 1200 BC, long before the glory days of classical Greece. There are other sunken sites in the world but this one seems to be one of the biggest of all time. Atlantis is unique than other sites because its considered to be planned towns. This myth lays about 30,000 square meters of ocean floor off the southern Peloponnese.               What they found in the ruins surpassed all expectations. It revealed a world of  buildings, courtyards, main streets, rock-cut tombs and religious structures. It was replete with thousands of shards of pottery. During this operation they also revealed over 9,000 square meters of  new buildings. More than any underwater site so far, the find offers potential insights into the workings of Mycenaean society. Elia Spondylis co-directed the survey as the head of Greece's underwater antiquities department. Marine geologists have yet to work out why the settlement sank. Theories include sea level changes, ground subsidence as the result of earthquakes, or a tsunami. As the world's oldest submerged city it is truly amazing. It not only shows how people lived at the time is also of great interest to natural scientists.              Locals in the nearby town of Neapolis are delighted. It is the first time a sunken city has been found in Greece that predates the time that Plato wrote his allegorical tale of the sunken continent of Atlantis. Atlantis was a myth but it is a myth that keeps underwater exploration going. This is an extraordinary find but there is still a lot more down there that has to be found.

The Important Discoveries of Ancient Civilizations                     The discoveries that archaeologists have made about these ancient civilizations like the Inca, the Pueblans, and the Pavlopetri are important to many people. Learning about the past and how they ran their city is very different and unique to the way we do it now. People believe that ancient civilizations have a lot of history behind it, that's why every discovery archaeologists make about these civilizations is important.                 The Incas ran their empire using colored strings to keep records. These colored strings were called quipus, the Inca made knots on them and also used them to record the calendar to keep a count of livestock. Archaeologists found clues left behind by the Inca that form an amazing portrait of their religion, art, and architecture, agriculture, government, transportation, and way of life. With these clues archaeologists can put together details of Inca life. Some of the old stories we know of the Inca are because they were written down by the Europeans who arrived in the empire in 1532, and also because of letters and diaries that described the Inca that Spanish soldiers had left behind. The rest of our knowledge of the Inca comes from artifacts, or objects that they left behind. The Inca artifacts might be objects made form stone, pottery, gold, or silver, these materials last a long time. Even if these things have been buried for hundreds of years, some turn up in the ruins of buildings, and others are found buried in graves for the dead to use in the afterlife.               The first Puebloans settled in Mesa Verde. They lived in pithouses usually built on mesa tops. The Puebloans began building houses above ground, from here on these people are known as Puebloans. Between A.D. 1100 and A.D. 1300 the population reached several thousand, that is when they started to improve their houses. Instead of pole and adobe they started using stone masonry, walls of thick, double-coursed stone often rose two or three stories high and were joined together into units of 50 rooms or more. The Puebloans are known for there magnificence buildings and stones.               The secrets of the lost city that may have inspired one of the world's most enduring myths, the fable of Atlantis has been brought to light form under the waters of southern Greece. What archaeologists found surpassed all expectations. The shifting sands and the settlement's enclosure in a protected bay, the exploration revealed a world of buildings, courtyards, main streets, rock-cut tombs and religious structures. They say the city sank in the sea around 1000 BC, and that the settlement dates back 5,000 years. Yet marine geologist have yet to find out why the settlement sank, theories say that it might be because of sea level changes, ground subsidence as the result of earthquakes, or a tsunami. This is the first time a sunken city has been found in Greece that predates the time that Plato wrote his allegorical tale of the sunken continent of Atlantis. Archaeologists have discovered many different artifacts from many different places. They all have on thing in common though, they are ancient civilizations. Three out of these many civilizations are the Inca, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri.       To begin, the Inca was an ancient civilization that ruled a South American empire for about a hundred years(1438-1532). Archaeologists found that trying to piece together this civilization wasn't going to be easy. They discovered a system of knots made with colored strings, called quipus, which was used to record the calendar and keep count of the livestock. Archaeologists have found many ancient quipus, but no one today knows what the knots mean. The Inca did however leave behind clues that helped give us a better understanding of what their religion, art and architecture, agriculture, government, transportation, and way of life was back then. The Inca lived high up in the Andes and they may have worshiped some mountain peaks. The sites were in remote, high areas, which made it difficult to reach them. Some of what we know came from oral history, but the rest came from the amzing artifacts that the Inca left behind.       Next, a group called the Puebloans, for more than 700 years, they and their descendents lived and flourished in Mesa Verde. The first Puebloans to settle in Mesa Verde were known as Basketmakers for their skill at craft. Farming then replaced hunting and gathering and became their main livelihood. These people live in pithouses which were cramped into small villages. Puebloans learned to make pottery and discovered the bow and arrow. They became 'smarter' and began to build houses above ground. Sadly though, the Puebloans left no written records and much of what was important has perished. Eventually the cliff dwellers left and traveled south into New Mexico and Arizona. Some of the Pueblo people, and maybe other tribes, are descendants of this interesting group.       Finally, the secrets of the lost city. Dr Jon Henderson once stated,' There is now no doubt that this is the oldest submerged town in the world.' Living in this town many years ago were people known as the Pavlopetri. This town was believed to have been consumed around 1000BC. Henderson found ceramics dating back to the end of the stone age, but what really took him by surprise was the discovery of a possible megaron. Now you might ask what a megaron is, well its a monumental structure with a large rectangular hall. This is the first time a sunken city has been found in Greece that predates the time that Plato wrote his allegorical tale of the sunken continent of Atlantis. This city has inspired one of the greatest myths of all time and to actually of found it was even better.       In conclusion, these three ancient civilizaions are very fascinating to archaeologists. Maybe one day you might discover something like this. It would be an interesting discovery dont you think? Maybe even one day, a hundred years from now, people will be learining about us and wondering what life was like when we lived.

Throughout the course of history, there have been many important discoveries. The uncovering of the Inca, Puebloan, and Pavlovian civilizations were crucial for the understanding of the past. Each civilization has unique customs and traditions, some of which we still use today. They also created many useful inventions that we've elaborated on and use on a very frequent basis.       For example, the Inca tied knots in colorful strings called the quipu, which is a device for keeping track of things, such as livestock and calendar dates. No one knows exactly what the knots mean. This invention helped to create the idea of calendars, calculators, and public records.        One other important discovery was that of the pithouses and kivas. Pithouses were homes set into the ground with a covering overhead and they were about the size of a living room. These later became kivas, which were places used for healing rites or to pray for rain, luck in hunting, or good crops. These are present-day churches and houses.        These inventions were very important to the development of present-day technology. They shaped the way we live today.

Murals and paintings can give us a sense of how things used to look when these civilizations existed. Buildings and other extraordinary structures show us how advanced they were architecturally and mentally. Some people don't understand the meanings of these spectacular artifacts, but we use many of the same techniques and styles they did now.

Archeologists who study these sites keep careful records. They write down and photograph any artifacts they find, and note the exact position in which they find them.They need to learn as much information as they can from every single piece of evidence.Archeologists can compare what they learn from artifacts and sites with the Spaniards' accounts of the Inca. If we do not learn about our history, we are doomed to repeat it. The Incas, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri are all societies that failed brutally. We must discover as much as we can about them so we do not make the same mistakes they did.       For example, in the passage 'Ancient India: Archaeology Unlocks the Secrets of the Past', it states 'Historians have to be careful when they interpret these accounts. The Spaniards did not speak the Inca language well. They may not have understood what the Inca told them, so their descriptions might not be accurate.' If we were not precise in discovering this historical significance, our society could have easily failed. The Spaniards were revolutionary conquerers. If we didn't know that the Incas were conquered, we might not have been as well-prepared for people trying to wage war or take over our society.       Also, in a later passage, known as 'Mesa Verde National Park ancestral Puebloans and Their World', it states 'when the cliff dwellers of Mesa Verde left, they traveled south into New Mexico and Arizona, settling among their kin who were already there.' Had historians not found this out, Americans might not have known about the vast ancestral differences in their country, which could have led to major social differences. This could completely change how we look at society today!       Even furthermore; in the article 'Lost Greek city that may have inspired Atlantis myth gives up secrets,' it is addressed that 'Explored by an Anglo-Greek team of archaeologists and marine geologists and known as Pavlopetri, the sunken settlemtn dates back 5,000 years to the time of Homer's heroes and in terms of size and wealth of detail is unprecedented, experts say.' Therefore, if we did not discover 'this site, which straddles 30,000 square meters of ocean floor,' we might not be as a ware of natural disasters and have the protection we need when a storm or flood comes.       Thanks to these historical evidences though, we can now live in a much, safer, well-protected, better inferred, and all-around happier society.

Mesa Verde was found about 1400 years ago, long before Europeans explored North America, the Mesa Verde lived in pithouses from about A.D. 550 to A.D. 750. the pithouse featured a living room sunk a few feet in the ground. Four coner timbers suppirted the roof. The firepit an air defector. About A.D. 750 they began building houses above ground, with up right walls made of poles and mud.They built the houses one against another in long, curving rows, often with a pithouse or two in front. In A.D. 1000 the people of Mesa Verde had advanced from pole-and-adobe construction to skillful stone masonry.                      The Lost Greek city. The secrets of the lost city that may have inspired one of the world's most enduring  myths —the fable of Atlantis— have been brought to light from beneath the water off southern Greece. The site, which straddles 30,000 square meters of ocean floor off the southern Peloponnese, is believed to have been consumed by the sea around 1000 BC. Although discovered by British oceanographer some 40 years ago, it was only this yeah that marine archaeologists, aided by digital technology, were able to properly survey the ruins.                        Thanks to the shifting sand and the settlement's enclosure in a protected bay, the exploration revealed a word of building, courtyards, main streets, rock-cut tombs and religious structures. In addition, the seabed was replete with thousands of shards of pottery.                         Marin geologists have yet to work out why the settlement sank. Theories include sea level change, ground subsidence as the result of earthquakes, or a tsunami.                         It is the first time a sunken city has been found in Greece that predates the time that Plato wrote his allegorical table of the sunken continent of Atlantis.

Ancient Civilizations and Artifacts       As time has gone by, many civilizations have been taken over or destroyed. But as technology improves, we discover many artifacts, buildings, and sometimes even a whole city! We have recently discovered many civilizations, but the most important ones are the Inca, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri civilizations.       The Inca Empire has been known for many years, but some people do not know much about them. The Incas were very interesting people. They built their empire on the Andes mountains because they wanted their enemies to have a hard time reaching them. There are many places in the Andes mountains that are Inca sites for artifacts, but most of them have been disturbed. They have been disturbed by looters because the Incas people had many valuable artifacts.       The civilization that was once in Mesa Verde was known as Puebloan. The Puebloans were also very interesting people because they were very skilled people. The archaeologists who study artifacts from Puebloans have found many pottery. The shape of the pottery varies in different shapes and sizes. The archaeologists have also noticed that most pottery have paintings on them. The paintings are very detailed and precise. this is evidence that the Puebloans were very talented and patient.       There has recently been a new civilization discovered by British and Greek archaeologists. Its name is Pavlopetri. This civilization is so unique because it is completely underwater. Archaeologists have studied many artifacts from here. They have discovered that it is very well preserved. It is well preserved because the shifting sands and protected bay protect the city from much damage. The archaeologists have also discovered that the city was filled with shards of pottery. This it evidence that the people of Palvopetri were also very skilled at crafting.       These civilizations were very important to discover and study because they teach us about what ancient civilization was like. People are very interested in ancient civilization because it is very different from what society is today. It is also very interesting because as society changes, so does technology. People want to know what technology was like in ancient times.

You probably are wondering how this worked for them, what the did was for an important event they would tie a new piece of string. They had certain colors for certain events. The Inca were very religious.               Clues left behind from the Inca from an amazing portrait of their religion, art and architecture, agriculture, government, transportation, and the way of life. By studying these clues, archaeologists and others were able to put things together and figure out there past.              The first Ancestral Puebloans settled in mesa Verde (Spanish for 'green table') about A.D. 550. They are also known as the basket-makers. because they have such high skills in arts and crafts. They learned to make pottery and acquired the bow and arrow for the help for hunting. At about A.D. 750 their population increased by a lot! Some of today's Pueblo people, and maybe other tribes, are descendants of the Ancestral Puebloans of Mesa Verde. Ancient Civilizations        By: Harlie Sell              In acient civilizations like the Inca of Peru, and the Puebloans of Mesa Verde; the artifacts and cities themselfs help archaeologists learn how the people of that time and place lived, thrived, and how they died.       The Inca people had no formal alphabet and they made nots in colorful pieces of string to record information, and these colorful pieces of string are called quipus. The Inca used these qiupus to record the calender and to keep track of livestock. The only written information that archaeologists could find was the journal entries of the Spanish Soldiers and priests that came to Europe in 1532.       The Puebloans of Mesa Verde lived in pithouses from A.D. 550 to A.D. 750. The pithouses had a living room that was sunk a few feet in the ground and had timbers to support the roof. At about A.D. 750 the Puebloans started building their houses above ground, with upright walls made with mud and wooden poles. The Puebloans then started making these homes in long curving rows,( often having a couple pithouses in the front) and these homes gave the Puebloans their name.

Lost Cilvilizations                  The discoveries that had been made from the Incas, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetris are imprortant because they were ancient civilizations that were here a long time ago.          The  Incas were important because they were very well known for their homes and great arcutectures. They were often found in the Andes and may have worshiped mountain peaks. They lived in high remote places like in caves in cliff faces or on mountain tops. The icy cold mountains acted like a gianted freezer by preserving their bodies for pber 5,000 years. Scienctists use modern medical scanning equipment to reaveal how they had lived and died.          The first Puebloans settled in Mesa Verde about A.D. 550. They were known as Basketmakers because they had good craft skills. They farmed instead of hunting and gathering. The first Puebloans live in pithouses, which included a living room and a sink a few feet in the ground, a four corner timber suppoted roofm a firepit and storage bins or pits clustered into small villages usually built on Mesa tops but also sometimes in cliffs. They learned how to make pottery, bow and arrows, and a spear thrower. They soon multiplied, about A.D. 750.          All of the ancient civilizations were very important for their agriculture and their way of living.

The discoveries made about the Inca, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri are important, because they uncover the secrets from the past and solve many doubts archeologists had about these cultures.       After the Spaniards arrived to South America, they recorded their days in their diaries. Here they wrote about their experiences and stories they heard as of every day. Although inaccurate, archeologists have used these writings to record Inca history and myths. This is due that Incas had no formal alphabet or system of writing. Inca artifacts and objects are used to find clues on Inca daily-life. Inca artifacts might be made of stone, pottery, gold or silver. Some of these are found in graves for the dead to use in the afterlife. Inca sites provide the best idea of all about life in Peru before and during Inca rule.       The Pavlopetri city, recently found underwater near Neapolis, is about 5,000 years old. The find offers potential insights into the workings of Mycenaean society. It is significant, because as a submerged site, it was never reoccupied. Theories of how this ciy sank include sea level changes, ground subsidence as the result of earthquekes, or a tsunami. It is very likely a combination of the first two. It is the first time a sunken city has been found in Greece that predates the time that Plate wrote his allegorical tale of the sunken continent of Atlantis.       The Puebloans first settled about 1,400 years ago in the region of Mesa Verde. Here, they began constructing homes and farms. The first Ancestral Puebloans settled in Mesa Verde about A.D. 550. They are known as Basketmakers for their skill in crafting. They lived in pithouses and they learned how to make pottery and acquired the bow and arrow. About A.D. 750 they began building houses above ground. By A.D. 1000 the people of Mesa Verde had advanced from pole-and-adobe construction to skillful stone masonry. Between A.D. 1100 and A.D. 1300 the population may have reached several thousand. About A.D. 1200, another major population shift saw people begin to move back into the cliff alcoves that sheltered their ancestors before.

Lost Civilizations           You may be wondering why discoveries about the Inca, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri are so important. Well, for starters, it all dates back to ancient Inca.                                                    The Inca            Although the ancient Inca of Peru had no formal alphabet or system of writing, they did make knots in colored string to keep record of livestock. If not for the clues left behind by the Inca , we would not known about this civilization that ruled the South American empire that rivaled the expense of ancient Rome for nearly a hundred years. These clues that the Inca left behind showed their way of life, transportation, government, religion, agriculture, and art and agriculture and with the knowledge of this, archaeologists pieced together the details of the Inca lifestyle.                                                All of what archaeologists know not only comes from artifacts of this civilization, but from the passing of stories from generation to generation.       The Puebloans              The first Puebloans were Ancestral and were known as Basketmakers for their skill at the craft. They settled in Mesa Verde about A.D. 550. They lived in pithouses clustered into small villages that were sometimes built on mesa tops or cliff recesses. Since they didn't hunt or gather as much, farming became their main way to food. They also took the time to make pottery and developed a more efficient weapon for hunting by replacing the atlatl with the bow and arrow.       The Pavlopetri           The Pavlopetri were explored by an Anglo-Greek team of archaeologists and marine geologists. The settlement was sunken and dated back to the time of Homer's heroes about 5,000 years ago, and in terms of wealth and size of detail is unprecedented.           Said to be the oldest submerged town in the world, Pavlopetri has remains dating back to 2800 to 1200 BC, years before the days of classical Greece. Archaeologists know that there are older, undiscovered sites in the world, but none can really be considered a planned town such as the Pavlopetri.           Lost Civilizations (cont.)           The discoveries of these lost civilizations are very important in history back then, and even today's history. Most of what archaeologists know about today's history comes from the discoveries of these lost civilizations, so before you think to yourself how boring early civilizations are to you, remember that these lost civilizations play a big role in our way of life.

The Ancient Incas:       The Artifacts are important because it can help the Archeologists figure out how the Incas, Puebloans, and Pavlopetri lived.  The Incas lived high in the Andes and may evem have worshiped some peaks.  Most of the Incas sites are in high places.  Living in high places preserve the sites, because looters cannot easily get to them.  The rest of our knowledge of  Inca comes from artifacts, or objects that they left behind, and from the sites where artifacts are found.  Some Inca Textile and clothing survived remarkably well.  Ancient material like cloth are usually destroyed by dampness, but these survived, because it has been preserved in the dry desert of Peru.       The Puebloans:       The first Puebloans settled in Mesa Verde (green table) about A.D 550.  The Puebloan are known as Basketmakers for their skill and craft.  The Puebloans lived in Pithouses from about A.D 550 to A.D 750, as settled agriculture began.  Pithouses have a living room sunk a few feet in the ground.  Four corner timbers the roof.  The firepit had an air deflector.  Pithouse will later on evolve to Kivas.  From here on these people are known as Puebloans meaning 'village dwellers.'  The Puebloans never left any written record and that was important in their lives perished.  The Puebloans has turned pithouses into kiva's.  Kiva is a Hopi word for ceremonial room.  The Puebloans were able to build and evolve/change pithouses into a Kiva throughout their lives.       The Pavlopetri:       The fable Atlantis have been brought into light from beneath the waters of Southern Greece.  The secrects of the lost city has been explored by an Anglo-Greek team of archaeologist and marine geologist known as Pavolopetri.  The site so far offers potential insights into the workings of Mycenaen society.  The Marine geologists have yet to work out why the settlement sank.  Atlantis was a myth but it is a myth that keeps underwater exploration going, said Sakellariou.  The myth of Atlantis has the archaeologists and geologists searching and trying to figure out why it even sank.       Having artifacts would make it easier or would at least give the scientists, archaeologist, and geologist a clue of what has been there.  Potteries, tools ect could help by telling how long they have been their and what sort of materials were used in order to build anything or make anything.

The Inca left behind many clues as to how they lived life. Due to the passing down of storeis and myths, archaeologists have found out their 'history'. Also, with the 'clues' the Inca left behind, we may be able to find out their religion, art and architecture, agriculture, government, transportation, and way of life. The Puebloans were/are known as basketmakers. They are also known for their houses, known as pithouses, and as they evolved into better structures, kivas. Puebloans were also one of the first tribes to also evolve from hunting and gathering to farming and having weapons for both. As they evolved into better structuers and better at farming, they learned to make pottery and more efficient weapons for hunting, like a bow and arrow. There have been many ancient discoveries in the past couple of years, namely Incas, Puebla, and Greek. These have all been made quite recently and shed insight on some of these cultures. More importantly however, it shows the ancient ways of life and tools of these groups, and may even develop our government even further than it is right now.       These groups may all be ancient, but what they lived in and where they lived was most certainly unique. Puebla Kivas might give us information about their past. These kivas obviously show us that the Puebla were religious, enhanced by the fact that they contained an 'entrance to the underworld'. As we can see from the Greeks, some chose to live in towns. Some of the Incas preferred more privacy, and chose to live in the mountains. Possibly more important than the shape or community these civilizations chose to live in are the locations. The Greeks lived near water. This means that they probably were not as worried about war, and might have lived off of seafood and foreign trade. In sharp contrast, the Incas lived in the Andes mountaintops and the deserts surrounding. Having the higher ground is an unmistakable advantage, which means they might have feared war more than starvation or running out of water.       Some of the tools made in each of these communities are still used today. The Greeks developed beautiful pottery, which has evolved into the plates and cups we eat and drink out of every day. The Puebla evolved the atlatl into a more complex, yet easier weapon to use, the bow and arrow. Archery was a typical war factor all the way until medieval times. and is still practiced for recreation and food today. Perhaps one of the most unique items developed in this time period was the Quipus. The quipus was developed by the Incas and was a way of keeping records by simple knots in string.       Can you imagine how much simpler life might be for government officials if we just did records in string? They would not have to worry about foreign countries seeing them, and we could put less time into preventing computer hackers and more time into working Obama's sixteen trillion dollar deficit down. This isn't the only thing we could learn, as we excavated the Incas, we learned that dry weather and freezing work very well for preservation. This has lead to more advanced coffins and chryrostasis. We could learn from their houses, for all the homeless people in the world. The ancient houses might be a good, affordable substitute for a modern house.       These advancements have all came from history, quite great accomplishments for people living in what we might consider the stone age. It is time for us to finally recognize that these ancient achievements are important; that they do really matter. All of these give us insight on what life might be like in the past, and possibly the future.

Do you know what happened 10 years ago? 50? 100? 1,000? That's what archaeoligists are trying to figure out. For years, the have studied the lost civilizations of the world; the Inca, the Greek, and the Anasazi. The archaeoligists are exploring many sights to link the past to the present. It hasn't been easy though.           The Incas were all wiped out by Spanish conquistadors in the 1500's. Extremely wealthy, everything in their society had a lot of value, so it was taken by the Spanish and looters. This makes it hard to find objects to deduct what happened. When an archaeoligist does find something, it is photographed and documented, dusted off, but not moved. The location is essential to proving historical accounts true and to deducting what the item was used for. The mountainous terrain and dangerous jungles also make it hard to access. Event though most artifacts were stolen, the Incans left more clues behind then the Anasazi.            The Anasazi were a group of Native Americans living in the southwestern USA. The only clue left behind from this group were many structures and some hunting weapons. The structures indicate that they were a religious and creative group of builders. One such structure is called a kiva, a ceremonial room for religion. is Little is known about the Anasazi. With Greek society, we have a lot more to go off of.           The Greeks were a prosperous empire until the Romans came and took over, destroying most of their culture. A Greek city said to have inspired the myth of Atlantis is currently underwater. The city is called Pavlopetri and it's the oldest submerged town in the world. It has many artifacts because being covered in water makes it hard to loot. The shifting of sand in the currents has revealed a huge planned city with streets and everything. Marine geoligists and archaeoligists are using the latest digital technology in exploring Pavlopetri.            The Incas, Anasazi, and ancient Greeks are cultures that are lost to us. We can still explore the buildings that survived what the people did not. Geography has gotten in the way and often, things have been stolen from the site. Though it's been no cup of tea, archaeologists will not stop until they have put the lost pieces of time back into the puzzle.

Without their work, history class would be a lot more boring and pointless because there would be no information that was more than 100 years old.  Without the discoveries that have been made about the Inca, Puebloans, and Pavlopetri, we would have no knowledge of what happened in South America and elsewhere long ago.        Some of the people who lived long ago were more technologically advanced than we think, and we can learn and use some of their ideas because archaeologists study artifacts and ruins.  Some of the discoveries made gave us valuable bits of information that are interesting to know.  For example, the Inca made their items out of materials like gold and silver, and we had yet to discover gold in 1800.  Also, the Inca ruled South America for around 100 years.  For this information, archaeologists had to find written records, and more importantly, interpret them.  It is harder than you think to understand ancient languages, especially the ones that are not in use today.         Without the discovered information, there would be gaps in our history of the world that would be awkward and strange.  But archaeologists are here to fill these holes with their discoveries of ancient civilizations.  These discoveries are some of the most important things to ever happen, so that people now can draw conclusions about what happened long ago and see the similarities and differences between their lifestyle and ours.  It is important to know about the way of life of civilizations long ago and also very interesting to know about civilizations long ago.

The discoveries pertaining to the Incans, Puebloans, and Pavlopetri hold great importance in the world of today.        Knowledge of the past world helps us better understand the world of today. Take, for example, the Inca quipus. It was a tool of string used to record the population of a Inca empire. It helped the rulers in understanding just who it was, and how many it was, they ruled over.        Ancient sites also tell us what the world was like at that period in time. Graveyards housing the dead show us how long Incas lived on average, which can help us determine fatality rates for generations after. They also show us diseases that may have killed off many civilizations, which we may link to some diseases today, and in turn ay help us find cures for those said diseases. Buried sites also show us what weather patterns may have been like, which may aid us in figuring out how civilizations may have effected the environment around them.        Discovering these ancient empires also shows u the mistakes they've made so we can learn from them.          Some mistakes may include improper civilization placement. Civilizations built high up in the Andes Mountains were prone to rockslides. The cave that many lived in were susceptible to collapse. Another mistake would be abuse of the land. The Puebloans faced this problem.        The over use of land led to less fertile soil. Improper use of water led to droughts. These are thing one must avoid when part of a rapidly growing empire.        These are several things that the world has built on or improved Without the important discoveries of past societies, what would our be like today?

The Inca's lived in Pithouses from about A.D. 550 to A.D. 750, as settled agruculture began. The pithouse featured a living room sunk a few feet in the ground. Four corner timbets supported the roof. The firepit had an air deflector. An antechaber might contain storage bins or pits. The sipapu was a hole for passage to the underworld, from whick the people had come. Pithouses later evolved into kicvas.       Using nature to advantage, ancestral puebloans built their dwellings beneath the overhaging cliffs. Thier basic construction meaterial was sandstone that they shaped into rectangular blocks about the size fo a loaf of bread. The mortar between the blocks was a mix of mud and water. Rooms averaged about six feet by eight feet, space enough for two or three persons. The life people lived back in the 1500s was a base for how we live today. People built shelters for protection, they gathered plants for medicine, animal leather for clothing, and sharpened sticks and stones for weapons. Now we improved our ways and now use cotton or wool for clothing, framed wood for houses, and projectiled type weapons.             We usually find these artifacts in caves up in mountains, called dwellings, which tell us that people lived here in these conditions, where it was cold. Importance of the Discoveries Made about the Inca/Puebloans           For years, scientists and historians have been busy making educated guesses and conclusions about the ancient civilizations. As fascinating as these time periods were, there was scattered information. Sometimes, archaeologists would have more information on one subject than the other. This made it difficult to figure out all the pieces of the puzzle.       Archaeologists had a really difficult time deciphering the Inca's language, as they barely had any written information or records. Something that was an astounding breakthrough however was a quipu. This was a 'device' that the Incas made and used. This wasn't any particular was of writing or keeping track of events, but it was a number system. A quipu had a bunch of different colored strings that symbolized many different numbers. The quipu was extremely vital and important because it showed that the Incans were capable of inventing their own number system.       In Mesa Verde, Puebloans were shown as intelligent by the important findings made by archaeologists and historians, as well as scientists. The Ancestral Puebloans found out their own unique way of building huts, or 'Pithouses'. These living spaces were extremely important findings because it showed how the Puebloans lived. Soon, Pithouses became even more complex when they evolved into 'Kivas'. Kivas were made of a more solid, almost stone-like, clay. Not everyone lived in a Kiva as they were used as a ceremonial room and often held rituals for healing or praying. Shortly after Kivas were made, people called Cliff Dwellings started appearing. As their name states, they lived in cliffs. The first reports of Cliff Dwellings were made by cowboys in the 1880's, and this is when archaeologists started getting interested. These cliff homes were very sturdy and provided excellent protection from weather and other dangers such as enemy tribes or wild animals.       If you've ever heard of an ancient civilization called Atlantis, you might recall hearing somewhere that it had been submerged into the ocean and renamed 'The Lost City'. For years on end, divers and archaeologists have been trying to uncover secrets and other information about this sunken city. Though it still remains a mystery, the finding that have been made so far are extremely important to uncovering a truth. In source #3, 'Lost Greek city that may have inspired Atlantis myth gives up secrets', the author states that a monumental structure consisting of a rectangular hall called a megaron was discovered. This means, that the settlements status was raised because these were usually used by an elite. Not only was a megaron found, but ceramics dating back to at least 5000 years ago were uncovered as well. This means that Atlantis would have been submerged a full 1200 years earlier than scientists originally hypothesized.       As mentioned thoroughly in all 3 sources, archaeologists made some extremely important findings that helped historians and other experts find out the real truths along the way.

The Inca, Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri are all very important to understanding how ancient life was lived. These ancient civilizations have provided sufficient information about how life was lived beofore modern times.        The Incans had no sort of system of writing or alphabet, but they did have a kind of number dvice called a quipus. This device was used by tying knots onto a rope, and using that to keep track of numbers. keep track of livestock and to record their calendar. This early system of record keeping was useful in the Incan empire, and showed us how advenced they were. Humans today have still never decoded the system, this shows how advenced they must have been to be able to come up with a complex code that only they could understand.        A group of people called the Puebloans were very helpful in understanding the weather and way of life these people had. They lived in 550 A.D. and were well known for being amazing basketmakers. This shows us that they had makings and certain plants that allowed for this. They also were very early farmers, instead of being hunters and gatherers. They were very advanced and built pithouses gathered in small villages on mesa tops. They were amazing engineers in the way they mastered making houses and basketweaving. Their techiniques of basketweaving are still used, and since they were so durable we have some today!        There is a legend of an underwater city off the coast of Greece. It is the oldest submerged city in the world, it is 30,000 meters of ocean floor. Though some people want to believe it was built underwater, it was really just sumberged much later after it was built, caused by earthquakes. Archaeologists ahve found ceramics and ruins, believed to have belonged to an ancient group of people called the Pavlopetri. We have learned taht they had pottery and an advanced social hierarcy, which is amazing.

Through archeologists we have discovered many differents things that have happened in the past. The ancient civilizations that used to occupy the land we live in today we have little knowledge of. Part in because of the inaccurate records and geographical difficulties. So archeologists go back to where it all originated from to see what happened and how these people lived.            The Inca who lived in present Peru did not use a letter system but instead used pictures and specially designed calendars. Some knowledge we have today comes from the oral stories that have been passed down through the generations. However many of the things we know about ancient civilizations comes from artifacts found in the cities of origin.            The people who lived in all these tribes lived in special ways unlike each other and constantly changing. Many archeologists are still learning and gathering information about these lost cities in ruin. They can determine how many people lived in the city, the conditions, and how they lived their everyday lives. Many old Spanish records are inaccurate due to the difficulty of having to learn the language of the people and not always understanding what they were saying.           Thanks to archeologists we have learned many things about the past and all the things that happened.

The ancient Inca of Peru had no formal alphabet or system of writing. They did not leave archives for historians to study. The Inca made knots in colored strings called quipus to record the calender to keep a count of livestock. The first Europeans to meet the Inca were amazed that they could run a huge empire using string to keep records. Archaeologists have found many ancient quipus but today no one who knows what the knots mean. Without anyone who can read the stories tied into the colorful strings, understanding the ancient Inca is a lot like solving a mystery.

Have you ever wondered if their are any lost cities out there in the world? Well, there are three recently discovered civilizations. There are the Inca's, the Puebloans, and the Palvopetris. These three cities are such an important find, because it links us with the lost past and inspires archaeologists to search for more lost lands. The Inca's used no form of writing, nor did they have an alphabet.     First, the Incas were a civilization that lived in the Andes. The Inca's were a civilization that had no alphabet or writing. The Inca's us quipus, or colored string, to record their calendar to keep count of their livestock. Noone still knows what the knots mean. We discovered about the ancient Incas by their clues left behind with architecture and paintings. We also know some about the Incas from stories past down from many generations, and Europeans wrote down about them. Since the Inca lived high in the Andes the dead bodies were frozen which helps us learn about how they died and lived.     Next, the Puebloans lived in Mesa Verde. They lived there for about 700 years until they left their homes and moved away. The Puebloans were very skilled at basketmaking and they were formally Nomadic, until they began to lead a more settled way of life. They farmed more than they hunt for food. They lived in pithouses that were clustered into small villages. By A.D. 1000, the Puebloans used stone masonry. In A.D. 1200 the population began to shift and they moved back towards the cliffs. They lived in these cliff dwellings for about 100 years until they they left.     Finally, the Palvopetris werew found in the ocean. They sank 5,000 years ago. It is the biggest submerged town in the world. It straddles 30,000 meters of the ocean floor. They had buildings, courtyards, mainstreets, and rock cut tombs. They had ceramics dating back from the end of the stone age. They had a town hall and the city was never reoccupied.     These civilations help archaeologists figure out about the past and inspire them to find more. the Incas, the Puebloans, and thePalvopetris were such an important find for archaeologists and helped ancient discoveries.

All of the discoveries made in ancient civilizations were very important. They help teach us about the past and what people did to survive in ancient times. The Inca, Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri all help support the information we use to teach kids all over the world today.       In ancient Inca, there was no alphabet or system of writing. The times have changed from way back then until today. Imagine your life today without the alphabet, it would be pretty hard. There definitely would not be texting. How did they survive? Archaeologists believe that they used knots on colored string to record the calendar and keep count of livestock. This seemed to work for them at the time, but without any other real form of recording things, understanding the Incans is like solving a mystery.       The Puebloans were very skilled. They invented many types of houses and are considered very good basketmakers. They also created farming to replace hunting and gathering as their main livelihood. Life would be very hard these days without the help of the Inca. We would not even know how to produce our own food. How would we have adapted to the old lifestyle?       Without the devastating blow to the Pavlopetri society, we probably would bot know how to predict disasters such as the weather. We also wouldn't know how to react to things such as earthquakes and tsunamis. This ancient ruin has greatly helped influence our warning system to help avoid people in the way of danger.       All of these ancient discoveries helped us gain the knowledge we have today. It has helped us to invent things such as computers and cars. Without the knowledge of how these things worked in the past, we gain no skill of building things for the future. So, thank the people who made these discoveries, because without them who knows where we would be today.

The discoveries made about ancient civilizations can be really important to us today. The discoveries made about the Inca, Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri can show this.       The Inca kept track of multiple things using nothing more than tied knots called quipus. They used these for everything from calendars to keeping track of their livestock. The Inca ruled South America for about 100 years, and their expanse rivaled that of Rome. While many sites have been looted for valuable items, many remained hidden. This is partially because many Inca cities were built up high on mountain tops. This keeps the looters from getting to them, so archaeologists have been able to find them undisturbed. They find many artifacts to show the history of the Incas and how they lived. These range from scraps of cloth to diaries that Spaniards kept when they visited them. All of these things contrubute to seeing the rise and fall of the Incas.       The ancient Puebloans are still shrouded in mystery. While much is known about them, such as the homes the lived in, there are still a few questions. However, scientists have learned much about them. They adopted an agricultural lifestyle at Mesa Verde. While there, the quality of their homes increased until they were building multiple-story buildings with intricate stonework. They were also know as great basketweavers, and archaeologists have found examples of changing the way the made pottery. Eventually, they moved to the space under the cliffs where they lived and learned for a while. Then, they went off south, to families in new Mexico and Arizona. The reason is still unknown, but there are theories. One is that after hundreds of years the land was depleted. This may still be in speculation, but there is a great many things known about the ancient Puebloans, and they were a great race.       The secrets of the sunken city have been partially brought to life, thanks to a team of Anglo-Greek archaeologists and geologists. For a long time, people have been told the myth of the lost city of Atlantis, and they may now be revealed as true. Protection form the elements has revealed a large city, full of buildings, and even shards of pottery all over the seafloor. These ruins date back to possibly 5,000 years ago, 1,200 years farther back than scientists previously thought. While these ruins were discovered 40 years ago, not until recently were they showed in such detail. Scientists think that it may have once been above ground, but sunk due to rising sea levels, earthquakes, and other natural events. Thanks to the astonishing discoveries of archaeologists, the myth of Atlantis may no longer be a myth.     In conclusion, many of us have a fascination with the people that lived long before us. The hard work of archaeologists have uncovered many secrets of the past that have quenched our thirst for knowledge. There are still many things to be learned, and one day we may finally learn all we want to know about those who lived in the past, such as the Inca, Puebloans, and Pavlopetri.

Ancient Civilization of Inca is very interesting. In the writing to the left, it talks about many different discoveries that they have either dug up and found, stories past down  from the Inca people in the past, or just simply looked around for items left behind.           For example, ancient Inca of Peru had no formal alphabet or system of writing, so because of this they made knots in colored strings called Quipus to record the calendar to keep a count of livestock. Archaeologists have found many of these ancient quipus, but today no one knows what the knots mean. Since nobody knows how to read or interpret what the colorful strings and knots are or stand for, it is very much like a mystery to the archaeologists.           Also, clues left behind  by the Inca form an amazing portrait of their religion, art, and architecture, agriculture, government, transportation, and way of  life. By studying these clues that they left behind, archaeologists can put pieces and details together to form what the Inca life was like.           Some of the Inca's history came from stories past down from generation to generation. Passing on the stories was a super important way to preserve a community's history. Archaeologists say that some of what we know are from stories that were written down by the Europeans in the 1530's. They wrote the Inca's stories down in diaries or in letters. But some of the Inca's history may be thought of as legends, because the Spaniards didn't speak the Inca language very well so some of the stories may not be true.          What we know today are very important facts about the Inca history found by are Archaeologists that work very hard to discover them.
