Ancient Discovery                                                                                                                                             The ancient of peru had no fomal system or alhabet of  writting. They did not leave archives for historians to study. The Inca made colored strings called quipus to record the calendar to keep a count of livestock. The first europeans to meet the inca were amazed that they could run a huge empire using strings to keep records.                                                                                                                                         Ancient Rome left clues behind by the Inca form an amazing portrait of their religion, art and architecture, agriculture, government, transportation, and way of life. By studying these clues, archaeologists and others can piece together detail of the Inca life. The fall of the Inca is easy to date because the Spainards murdered the last Inca king in 1532 and took over the empire.            Ancient materials like cloth are usually destroyed by dampness, but these have been preserved in the dry deserts on peru`s coasts or the cold mountains or the andes. Some inca sites have been disturbed by treasure hunters or looters, Who take anything that might be valuable. Some treasures were taken centuries ago, but looting still goes on today. looted sites often do not tell archaeologists, who can dig them up carefully. They provide the best idea of all about life in peru before and during Inca rule.               Mesa Verde National Park preserves a spectacular reminder of this acient culture. Archeologists have called these people Anasazi, from a Navajo word sometimes translated as ''the acient ones'' or ''ancient enemies.'' We now call them Ancestral Puebloans, reflecting their modern descents. The first Ancestral puebloans settled in Mesa Verde (Spanish for ''green table'') about A.D. 550. They are know as basketmakers for their skill at the craft. Formerly nomadic, they were beginning to lead a more settled wayof life.              The structers are evidence of a society that, over centuries, accumulated skills and traditions and passed them on from generation to generation. By the classic Period, Ancestral Puebloans were heirs of a virgorous civilization, whos accomplishment in community living and the arts rank among the finest expressions of human culture in North America using nature to advantage, Ancestral Pueblanos built their dwellings beneath the overhanging cliffs. Their basic construction  material was sandstone that they shaped into rectangular blocks about the size of a loaf of bread. Explored by an Anglo Greek team of archealogists and marine geologists and known as pavlopetri, the sunken settlment dates back some 5,000 years to the time of Homer`s heroes and in term of size and wealth of detail is unexprecedented, experts say. The enclosure in a protected buy, the exploration revealed a world of buildings, courtyards, main streets, rock-cut tombs and religious structures. The lost city is important find because its very big and very old. It's also been there for many years. It was very replete with thousands of shards of pottery. The fable of Atlantis have been brought to light from beneath the waters off southern Greece.       The site, which straddles 30,000 square meters of ocean floor off the southern Peloponnese, is believed to have been consumed by the sea around 1000 BC. It was revealed over 9,000 square meters of new buildings. THe sunken settlement dates back some 5,000 years to the time of Homer's heroes and in terms of size and wealth of details is unprecedented, experts say. There was many things found in the lost city like old tools, weapons, money, coins and old pottery. There are older sunken sites in the world but none can be considerd to be planned towns such as this, which is why it is unique. More than any other underwater site so far, the find offers potential insights into the working of Mycenaean society. 40 years ago it was only the year that marine archaeologists, aided by digital technology, were able to properly survey the ruins. Theories include sea level changes, ground subsidence as the result of earthquakes, or tsunami.       The Atlantis was a myth but it is a myth that keeps underwater exploration going. Greece was the first time that a sunken city has been found that predates the time that Plato wrote his allegorical tale of the sunken continent of Atlantis. The Importance on our Past                There are many different cultures and groups that are important to learn throughout history.  Many people could learn from them and see how we humans have evolved throughout the years.  I am going to explain why it is important using the Inca and the Puebloans as examples.            The Inca of Peru, were known to rule a South American empire for almost a hundred years.  They do amazing art work and are very imaginative.  For example, the Inca have created a record calendar using colorful strings to help keep count of livestock called quipus.  You can also see by the way they do their architecture, agriculture, and government.  Some of what scientists know about them have come from stories that have been passed down each generation to generation.  They are still trying to uncover their past by looking at the many artifacts that have been left behind, though some have been stolen, because of its value, by treasure hunters and looters.            The first ancestral Puebloans, meaning 'village dwellers' in Spanish, were found in Mesa Verde at around A.D. 550.  They were known as skilled basket makers that lived in pit houses.  These people have been evolving themselves by changing the way they do things over time.  For example, the thing that they have changed the most might have been their houses and how they would build them differently to make more efficient for living.  They went from the pit house when they first started out, to the kivas in A.D 750, back to the cliff alcoves in A.D 1200.  We can look at them as an example to try and make our lives better by evolving in our own lives and not having to do the same thing over and over again.            History isn't just reading about the things people have done in the past.  I have been hearing students say over and over again, why we have to take it as a class.  It is so we can learn about those people and try not to follow their mistakes if they have one any.  Anyway, history can be fun and see what kinds of things have been improved over time.  Everyday, people have been thinking of great ideas on how to make our life easier, safer, and, and more efficient.  For example, the Inca were smart and imaginative group of humans that used things in a way that we wouldn't have, like the knots of string.  We can see all around us that we can be just like those people that we have learned today to make our future generation better than what we might have now.

Lost civilizations are often difficult to find, learn about, and share. Three of these 'lost civilizations' include the Inca, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri. These three civilizations are significant because they all contributed something important to the human race and proof is rare.        The Inca worked well with things normally used for a simple task such as string. This was very important because this enabled them to make knowledge of a simple resource and use it to their advantage. This civilization was able to keep count of livestock by placing a colored string on them. The Inca also left pottery, stone, silver, and gold behind. This showed that they were skilled enough to find valuable materials, create art to trade, and hide their important things. Inca people were often buried with their belongings. This helped prevent stealing to a certain extent as well as confusion and fighting amongst the other Inca members.        The Puebloans were very skilled builders who built very detailed stone communities. This allowed them to stay safe from outside attacks and were able to move easily and resettle. Having this skill might be important because in case of emergency, they might have had to know an easy way to save themselves. This was also very helpful in the sense of outdoor materials. This lead them to know what they could or could not make a community out of, how well it would work, and how durable it would be. Puebloans produced the finest of expressions of the human race and that made them well known and admired. Kivas might helped the citizens to find an easy place for hunting/fishing which made it easy to feed their community and families. These members were able to make fir which was important because it allowed them to stay warm and welcome the village (source #2).        Finally, the Pavlopetri were skilled in areas such as ceramics and monument structures. Source #3 states: ''We found ceramics dating back to the end of the stone age, which suggested that the settlement was occupied some 5,000 years ago, at least 1,200 years earlier than originally thought,'' This, to me, means that this civilization was very experienced in trade and elegant forms of art from that time frame. This was important because that meant the Pavlopetris were able to trade and move around as much as they wanted. Since the 'ceramics' were found in the sea, that obviously meant they were strong, durable, and hefty which was important for carrying and transporting goods.       For these reasons and many others, I believe the Inca, Puebloans, and Pavlopetri were important civilizations.

The Inca were very interesting people. They did not have a formal alphabet or system of writing. They kept records with knots called quipus. They made a lot of pottery and art decorated with pictures and colors. The Fall of the Inca was in the year 1532 when Spaniards murdered the last Inca King and took over. The Inca lived high in the Andes and worshiped some mountain peaks. Most of their sites were in remote, high places. This helped preserve the sites because it was more difficult for looters to get to them. It makes it difficult for archaeologists to get to it though. They have to carry their equipment up and down the mountain, and they have to carry artifacts down the mountain for study. Bodies found in the icy Andes are in such good shape, the archaeologists could even figure out how the person died!                                                                                                                                                 The Puebloans lived about 1,400 years ago, dating long before Europeans explored North America. Puebloans chose Mesa Verde for their home at around A.D. 550 and lived there for more than 700 years. They made elaborate stone communities in the sheltered alcoves of the canyon walls. They made pithouses In the late A.D. 1200's, they left their homes and moved away. They are known as Basketmakers for their skill at the craft. Farming replaced hunting and gathering as their main livelihood.

Why are the discoveries that have been made about the Inca, the Puebloans, and the Pavlopetri so important? They play a huge role in discoveries of ancient civilization. The Incas had no formal alphabet system or system of writing. Puebloans are known as basketmakers for their skill at the craft. The marine geologists that studied the Lost City of Atlantis are known as Pavlopetri.            The Incas did not leave archives for historians to study. Clues left behind by the Inca form an amazing portrait of their religion, art and architecture, agriculture, government, transportation, and way of life. By studying these clues, archeologists and others can piece together details of Inca life. Passing on stories was an important way to perserve a community's history. The rest of our knowledge of the Inca comes from artifacts, or objects that they left behind, and from the sites where the artifacts are found.            This was a very important time for the Basketmakers, and their population multiplied. They began to built houses above ground, with upright walls made of poles and mud. From here on these people are known as Puebloans, the spanish word for 'village dwellers.' By A.D. 1000 the peopole of Mesa Verde had advanced from pole-and-adobe construction to skillful masonry. walls of thick, double-coursed stone often rose two or three stories high and were joined together into units of 50 rooms or more.            Explored by an Anglo-Greek team of archeologists and marine geologists and known as Pavlopetri, the sunken settlement dates back some 5,000 years to the time of Homer's heroes and in terms of size and wealth of detail is unprecedented, experts say.

Discovery of the Ancient cities          How do we know about a civilization that for nearly a hundred years ruled a South American empire that rivaled the expanse of ancient Rome? The Inca left clues behind that form an amzing portrait of their religion, art, and architecture, agriculture, goverment, transportaion, and a way of life. Archaeologists and others can piece together details of Inca life by studying these clues. Some of the stuff we know about them, comes from oral history, or stories passed from generation to generation. We know some of the stories because they were written down by the Europeans who arrived in the empire in 1852. The rest of our knowledege comes from artifacts and from the sites where they found. The artifacts were made out of stone, pottery, gold, or silver. Such materials last a long time, even if they have been buried for hundreds of years. Some of the textiles and clothing have survived remarkably well. Usually they would have been destroyed by dampness, but they were preserved in the dry deserts on Peru's coasts or the cold mountains of the Andes.             About 1,400 years ago, before Europeans explored North America, a group of people living in the Four Corners region chose Mesa Verde for their home.Archeologists have called these people Anasazi, from the Navajo word sometimes translated as ' the  ancient ones' or ' ancient enemies.' The first Ancestral Puebloans settled in Mesa Verde about A.D. 550. They were known as the Basketmakers for their skill at the Craft. Farming replaced hunting and gathering as their main livelihood. They lived in pithouses clustered into small villages usuall built on mesa tops but sometimes in cliff reccess. They learned to make pottery and acquired the bow and arrow, a more efficient weapon for hunting than the atlatl. About A.D 750 they began building houses above gorund,with upright walls made of poles and mud. By A.D 1000 the people of Mesa Verde had advanced from pole-and-adobe construction to skillful stone masonry.             The site straddles 30,000 square meters of ocean floor off the Southern Pelloponnesse, is believed to have been consumed by the sea around 1000 BC. Although discovered by a British oceanographer some 40 years ago, it was only this year that marine archeologists, aided by digital technology, were able to properly survey the ruins

For hundreds of years people from all over the world have been searching for lost pieces from the past to learn more about history. Because of those findings we have gotten pieces or starting points for the basis of our technology. Without some of the Incan's highway system we would not have long highways or messaging systems, and without the Puebloans we would not know how to make sandstone or adobe bricks with a unique morder. History has gave us many reference points and examples to show us how to live our lives and advance beyond our technology.   In 1438 to 1532, the Incans ruled most of what is now South America. They made different veriatys of textiles, pottery, jewelry, and buildings. Later in 1532, when the Spaniards arrived, most of the Incans' stuff where looted or disposed of. Now when archaeologists find these, they can understand more about the Incan life styles. Even now we not only get information about the Incan from their stuff, we also get it from Spanish journals or letters. Thanks to the Incans we got a base for our technology that we have now.\   About 1400 years ago, before North America was discovered and explored, people known as the Puebloans inhabited the four corners. They lived in an area known as Mesa Verde (now Mesa Verde National Park). They mostly specialized and are known for their building methods. They built huge walls, diverse housings, and different types of bricks. When a cowboy discovered these structures, study began on it. Now we understand how they made these bricks and what they used them for.   Poeple form all over the world spend their lives searching and studying different artifacts from different civilizations, trying to unlock their pasts. Most of those findings served as a basis for our technology we have now. Without some of the Incan's highway system we would not have long highways or messaging systems, and without the Puebloans we would not know how to make sandstone or adobe bricks with a unique morder. Thanks to the past we have a better view of the future.

We may not think of it very often, but without the discoveries we have made about the Inca, the Pueblos, and the Pavlovian, we would not know how technology has evolved or where it came from. Each ancient civilization played a very important key role in the change we have had in technology over time.             The ancient Inca of Peru lived high in the Andes mountain range where the climate would get extremely cold. Each civilization had their own ways of worshiping and had their own beliefs of what one should do with a dead body, whether they believed in the concept of the afterlife or not. In the Inca's case, dead bodies were simply buried in the surface of the mountains where they were well-preserved. When experts discovered these bodies in such good condition, their first question was how these people died and were able to use modern medical scanning equipment to figure it out. This way, medical experts can discover what diseases may have hit the Incas.             The First Ancestral Pueblos of Mesa Verde were formally nomadic but began to lead a more settled lifestyle. They were originally hunters, but evolved to farmers. As they settled, they began to adapt to their new lifestyle and started to build houses called pit houses in small villages and got more crafty since that they had one place to be. They were known for their skills in basket making, making pottery, and acquiring the bow and arrow and spear. By archeologists discovering these ancient artifacts, we piece together how we got the structures of our homes today; where they evolved from and maybe even where we got the idea from to make the modern weapons we use today.            The discovery of Pavlovian, the sunken city beneath the seas off of southern Greece also know for the fable of Atlantis, dates back to at least five thousand years ago. This once lively city takes up 30,000 square meters of the ocean floor and is thought to have sunken around 1000 BC. While marine archeologists dove down to search this city for any lost items that may still be in good enough condition to study, they found roads, thousands of broken pieces of pottery, religious structures, ceramics, and courtyards. These findings can help us understand the religion that the ancient people followed and the use of technology that they already had before us.            Our discoveries of the ancient Inca, the first ancestral Pueblos, and the Pavlovian helps us to figure out where all of our modern day technology started from. Without our findings of all the ancient artifacts, we would be lost in thought about where it all came from. From the way that dead bodies were buried to how their architecture influenced our modern architecture today, the ancient people really did play a key role in history.

Have you ever wondered how do we know so much about the past? How is it thats archeologists make these predictions about the past? First, archeologists are people who study ancient artifacts. Know that you know this, archeologists get sent to a specific location where ancient civilisations were located at. Now they dig up objects that give them clues about how that specific civilisation lived. They look at the material they are made out of, how they are made, and why they are made. Once, they obatain this information they will get how they lived.             Let's take a look at how the ancient Incas lived. Some of these civilisations were located at the mountains or at the coasts of Peru. Knowing the location of the civilisation will give up information about what they coulod've eaten or harvested. also this can explain how they got their materials to creat their clothes and pottery.            Also, another great ancient civilisation was the Puebloans. This civilisation was known for its hunting skills and because they were nomadic. They created an efficient weapon for hunting called the atlatl. This weapon was also know as a spear thrower, which made catching their pray easier.             Finally, an important civilisation thought of as a myth is Atlantis. this civilisation was thought of as a myth due to the fact that people thought cities couln't be floating water. But scientists have found walls and even buildings under the deep, deep ocean. This has many people amazed at how this city was created there, how did they live there and what did they do, and why it end up in the bottom of the ocean.              To sum up, archeologists are making new discoveries on ancient civilisations and will keep finding more. Archeologists might even end up lokking on how our culture worked and what our life styles were like.

Each civilization is unique and explains an old way of life that was once very modern. The discovery of the ancient Inca, Puebloan, and Pavlopetri civilizations are important because they provide a look at our past and how people lived thousands of years ago.       The Inca civilization is important because from it, archaeologists can learn about why they lived in the Andes mountains and how they used to adapt to life. The incans were good farmers and weapon builders. Archaeologists have found well preserved bodies, artifacts, weapons, and evidence of crops and farms. From this, the world can learn about how the past used to be and how different we are today.       The Puebloan civilization is a unique discovery and is important because it used to be a well developed and successful society. Puebloans had great arcitectural achievments and tools. Archaeologists have found many artifacts and clues to allow them to be able to solve the mysteries of other civilizations.       The Pavlopetri civilization is a huge deal because it proves that there may be other underwater cities and societies. The civilization is still preserved and allows a look at an old Greek way of life. Archaeologists can relate this civilization to other Greek civilizations and solve clues that they were unable to do before.       The Inca, Puebloan, and Pavlopetri civilizations have allowed archaeologists and the world to know more about our past and what we can do to make our future better.

In the articles, ' Ancient Inca: Archaeology Unlocks the Secrets of the Past by Beth Gruber and 'Mesa Verde National Park Ancestral Puebloans and Their World' by Roy Anderson, we, as a socitey can thoroughly understand the importance of found discoveries made by Archaeologists and Historians.           Artifacts founded by archaeolgoists have greatly impacted our society today. As we look back on past civilizations that have come before us, we can identify that some of things that we do to this day have originated from such societies as the Incas, the Puobelans, and the Pavloetries. For example, Incans made knots in colored strings to record the calender and keep count of their. Little dow e know, we could have been using the exact same stuff as them, but in a more advanced and technological way.         In addition, in the article 'The First Ancestral Puebloans in Mesa Verde' the author states that, 'They learned to make pottery and acquired the bow and arrow.' We have taken some of the Puebloans' ideas and ways of life and used it in our own lives in a more advanced way that can be more beneficial towards us and what our society consists of.         Another way that we, as Americans have accustomed some of the tools and crafts made by past civilazations are things like houses. In about 750 A.D., Incans began to construct houses of their own by building them above ground with upright walls made of poles and mud. Becoming more and more advanced, the civilazations' homes were constructed in a similar way as ours are today. Meaning that we most likely have used their ideas and ways of life and have gone based on that but more advanced in new ways.         All in all, the fact that Historians and Archaeologists have been continually discovering more artifacts and past civilazations is a beneficial thing for our socitey so we become more aware and knowledgable on where we jhave accustomed some tings that we still use today.

The discoveries of the Inca, Puebloans, and the Pavloperti and very important for several specific reasons.         The Inca civilization gives clues about life today. They had many different artifacts such as quipus that are important because we have evolved from that and developed a number system to keep track. However, the ancient Inca's did not had an alphabet or a number system.         The ancient Puebloans built houses that probaly have influenced todays house building. Todays homes are made up of several differeent materials, but they used to be made up of poles and mud. We may not have shelters today if the Puebloans hadn't began making these houses.        The Pavloperti was an extraordinary towm with buildings, courtryards, tombs, streets, religious structures, and pottery.

The ruins and remains of civilizations which lived thousands of years before modern times can help teach scientists and archaeologists about life in those times. Ancient buildings, pottery, and clothes can help us learn about the religion and life of those times. When archaeologists discover artifacts and ruins, they can find their depth in the ground to see their age. The deeper the object, the more time dirt and sand have to cover it. Therefore, the object is older. This is called carbon dating.        Ancient artifacts and ruins help us learn the lifestyle of the people who lived in them. Archaeologists can learn about the general life of people, their government, religion, and the roles of different classes of people.        Ancient ruins may help humans in the future, as we can learn from the mistakes of past civilizations. We may learn both the actions we should make, and how they may help or hurt society.
